name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for one-minute speeches on important political issues (Article 163 of the Regulation).

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Indeed, I consider calming the situation in Ukraine to be a priority, not only for Slovakia, the country where I come from, but also for the whole of the European Union. Peace on the European continent has not been threatened since the end of the Second World War as it is threatened today. While the Russian occupation and intervention result in chaos, destruction and suffering of the people, our activities are directed towards calm, stability and development. Even today, the situation is not easy, and it is necessary to name the facts clearly, the fact that people are still suffering and dying today must be seen. Therefore, everything must be done to peacefully resolve this conflict, which is possible only while maintaining the territorial integrity of the country and the complete departure of Russian soldiers from all over Ukraine. I believe that the forthcoming parliamentary elections will also contribute to calming the situation for the security, peace and prosperity of the people, not only in Ukraine, but throughout the European Union.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: Madam President, European citizenship needs to believe in Europe again and that will only be possible if we reverse the situation and generate confidence, growth and employment. European citizenship is exhausted from so much austerity, so many cuts and exponential growth in inequality. It is not enough to announce plans to re-industrialise Europe: they must be carried out with 'fresh' money, with real money, with extra money. We must promote the construction of transport and energy infrastructures, and revitalize the commitment to innovative industries; credit must be unlocked so that small and medium-sized enterprises can breathe, invest, generate economic activity and, consequently, employment, which is particularly important for countries such as Spain and for regions such as mine — Galicia – in the face of a serious economic and demographic crisis, and that it needs this European push to return to the path of convergence. Yesterday we ratified the Commission: it is necessary to get to work without dilation and without excuses.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Madam President, I would like to take this opportunity to draw attention to developments in the Czech Republic in the field of consumer protection in the telecommunications market.  Parliament in the Czech Republic has adopted an amendment to the Electronic Communications Act, on the basis of which the position of the participants in the contract will deteriorate, both consumers, sole traders and small business owners. I consider it most serious personally that the right of all customers to withdraw from the subscriber contract will be undermined in a situation where the operator unilaterally changes the essential elements of the contract. These requirements will be determined in the future by the operator, not by law.  Why am I saying this? According to many experts, such legislation may conflict with the content of the Universal Service Directive. I therefore considered it appropriate to raise this issue here in the European Parliament, and at the same time I would like to say that I will address the written question to the Commission in order to say whether or not the regulation is contrary to the Directive.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I come from Italy, in particular from a college, which unites Sicily and Sardinia, where the youth unemployment rate has reached almost 60% compared with an already high national rate of 44%, with dramatic human and economic consequences. In June 2013, the Council ruled that the European Union would mobilise all available instruments to support youth employment. So is it inevitable for me to ask myself and ask this Parliament, the Commission, the Council, whether the lack of results is due to the fact that not all the instruments available have really been mobilised or to the fact that these instruments, even if fully used, are not sufficient? Dealing with unemployment in Europe must be the priority for the coming years, both for the Member States and for the European institutions, which have the task of drawing the line for economic recovery, including by giving flexibility to the Member States. Finally, I hope that the EUR 300 billion announced by Juncker will be used for employment.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: I strongly object to the inadmissible and illegal intervention of the Republic of Turkey in the internal affairs of the Republic of Bulgaria – a sovereign state, a member of the European Union. For more than 20 years, the Republic of Turkey has intervened in our internal affairs by organising elections on its territory in contravention of Bulgarian electoral law, contrary to all good practices, good norms and good manners. This situation deteriorated further with the election of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, who did not hide his neo-Ottoman ambitions for the restoration of the Ottoman Empire. After these elections, in the last elections held in Bulgaria last month, more than 60,000 votes were organized by the Republic of Turkey, in violation of our electoral law, and changed the electoral result in a number of Bulgarian cities, which sparked protests in Gabrovo, in Dupnitsa, in Kyustendil and in other cities. This practice, as well as Erdogan's support for Islamic State, show the non-European nature of Turkey and show that this country has no place in the European Union.

name: Yana TOOM
text: Madam President, I will also speak about the severe humanitarian crisis in Ukraine. Firstly, Ukraine faces an energy crisis. In numerous Ukrainian cities, including Kiev, there is no hot-water supply and central heating may not work properly during the coming winter. The prices of utility services, including water, are rapidly increasing and people will be unable to pay bills. Secondly, there are the consequences of the armed conflict. There are several hundred internally-displaced persons. Some of them have no income and appropriate housing. Their access to social and medical assistance is limited. In some parts of eastern Ukraine, the local infrastructure has been destroyed. We can expect a serious shortage of food, and of food at an affordable price. Thirdly, the general efficiency of the Ukrainian state apparatus is hindered by large-scale corruption and inflated bureaucracy. The humanitarian situation in Ukraine must be urgently addressed, in particular in the light of the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement. However, any assistance has to be provided under scrutiny and with the technical assistance of the European institutions, while the Ukrainian authorities prove to be inefficient in providing assistance to internally-displaced persons.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Madam President, in southern Europe, I say memoranda, the policy of mass divestment is being promoted. Same in Cyprus. The troika, together with the Cypriot government, are trying to impose on the Cypriot people legislation, which will lead to massive seizures of very small houses and professional roofs, thus leading to the dissolution of small and medium-sized enterprises and the creation of a homeless society.  We believe that the Divestment Act should target large debtors, but also protect vulnerable families and small businesses. With interventions brought about in the government bill by the majority of the parties in the Cypriot parliament we managed to protect the small professional housing and the main residence.  But the troika and the government are sticking to their own claims. They are blackmailing that if we do not accept what they have agreed then the tranche of the European Stability Mechanism will not be disbursed. By blackmailing, they seek the human right of the roof to be sacrificed on the altar of supposedly banking consolidation of barbaric austerity policies. We demand an end to analgesia, we call on the European Parliament to fulfil its role.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Madam Vice President, with this speech I want to point out a very important problem in Croatia, a problem that creates serious and severe consequences on the environment and the health of citizens. Responsibility for this unbearable situation lies with the refinery in Bosanski brod in Bosnia and Herzegovina.  Citizens and citizens of slavonski brod are daily victims of cross-border air pollution of the mentioned refinery owned by the Russian company Zarubežnjeft. The measuring station in slavonski brod records high concentrations of several pollutants that put the health of citizens of the eastern part of Croatia at risk and pollute its environment. Given that Bosnia and Herzegovina has not yet ratified the agreement with the European Union, I think political pressure is the only course of action. Concrete solutions are needed.  It is essential to reduce emissions of pollutants that last for a long time as soon as possible. Equality of all EU citizens and ensuring a healthy and sustainable environment for a healthy and quality of life for all citizens should be the supreme value of the European institutions, but also a motivation for stronger and more purposeful action in solving this serious European problem.

name: Giulia MOI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, since the 1950s NATO has transformed Sardinia into a large area of essential war services, where all kinds of exercises take place. This region is used as a fuel depot, as evidence, as a ground to practice and leave pollution. They damaged the territory and the archaeological sites that were part of it. They have irreparably damaged millennial nuraghi, recognized as a World Heritage Site by UNESCO.  There is also a very high risk that these experimental polygons will also harm human health. There is a risk of fine dust, thorium, uranium 238 and the high number of malformations and leukaemia in the territory is worrying. When they have finished experimenting, it will be so polluted that it will be impossible to live there. All this makes the mapping of areas at risk no longer procrastinating, a reclamation plan to be adopted. I ask for the help of the European Union.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Mr. President, on the market of the Republic of Croatia from other countries, among them are the countries of the European Union, comes food that is much lower in price, but also of much lower quality than domestic food. Under special public scrutiny in recent days, pigmeat, which due to the Russian embargo has been on the market more than usual, and which has been frozen stored for several years, thawed, repackailed and subsequently frozen.  It arrives on the Croatian market without the specified date of slaughter, but only the expiry date is highlighted, which is obviously re-established with each new freezing and repackaging period. If we know that all relevate research shows that meat loses quality if it stands longer than a year of death, it can be said that those who place meat on the Croatian market up to 7 years old commit a crime against consumers who consume this meat, and do not have accurate information about what they actually eat. If such products are not good for the inhabitants of other members of the European Union, then they are not good for Croats either, so I call on the European Commission to put an end to such unfair trading practices.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: In the art world, artists of nonverbal works – music, sculpture, ballet – communicate without barriers with the audience of each country, regardless of the language in it. This does not apply to authors of literary works that need to be translated. Today in European bookstores you will almost not see a book in Bulgarian, Romanian, Polish, Hungarian author. The European Commission has a Creative Europe department that funds translations of books from 15-20 works instead of single works. When the translation is financed, the author receives a level playing field in the multi-linguage European territory.  Any book-writer who has judged that a book by an author in the European Union is worth printing and distributing should receive direct funding from the European Union for translation under a simplified procedure, and I call on the European Commission to adopt this approach.  That way we'il give the talented artist a chance to break through. As the author of two books, I know that the correct criteria is the judgment of the publisher and the reader. This will not discriminate against smaller European languages, and the European Union will reject linguistic discrimination, one of the last on its territory.

name: James NICHOLSON
text: Madam President, on 7 October this year, JTI, the tobacco making company, announced the closure of its Lisnafillan factory in Ballymena, Co. Antrim, in Northern Ireland, with the loss of 900 jobs in that area – and that is only in the immediate factory, there are hundreds more jobs in SMEs, printers and haulage companies throughout the area. That closure was caused by the actions and decisions made in Europe on the second tobacco products (TPD2) packaging directive. Those jobs have been closed. Let those who made those decisions go and tell those poor people in Ballymena today what their future is. How will they pay their mortgages, how will they bring up their families and how will they look to a future? I am certainly looking to Europe to come back in and help to do the best they can through the Globalisation Fund, to do all they can for the people of Ballymena.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Madam President! I would like to take this opportunity to raise our awareness of the issue of the euro. This common currency was created to bring growth, stability and prosperity across our continent. Today, in the light of the figures, exactly the opposite is manifesting itself. States' debt levels are exploding. Private debt is exploding. Purchasing power is constantly dwindling due to Mr Mario Draghi's zero interest rate policy. We have de facto 0% key interest rates and real, real measurable inflation of surely beyond 5%. Many people can no longer afford to live. Look at the area of food, the gastronomy, for example: many people can no longer work out at the back and in the front. What we urgently need now is to stop this series of attempts to rescue the euro in this way, because it has brought us more and more into the crisis. Separation in the north and south of the euro would be a way of bringing stability back into our continent.

name: Andor DELI
text: Madam Vice-President, with regard to the Solidarity Fund, I believe that there is a need for greater flexibility and speeding up payments for the Member States eligible for the aid, and in particular for the candidate countries which are also eligible for the aid. This is particularly true for Serbia, which was hit by severe flooding in the spring, exacerbating the country's difficult economic situation and energy dependency, while it received perhaps the most positive country report from the countries in the region from the European Commission. Effective and rapid support from the EU can give Serbia's leaders the strength to persevere in this sensitive and complex foreign and security policy situation through European integration and the construction of a strong rule of law. Preserving peace and stability is the EU's top priority, and this is particularly important for Hungary, as it is well known that there are 250,000 Hungarians in Serbia, one of whom is me.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: Madam President, in the past five years, the EU has helped broker a deal on Iran’s nuclear weapons, Syria’s dismantling of chemical weapons and Belgrade’s dialogue with Pristina. Two years ago, the EU received the Nobel Peace Prize. I am proud of the EU and its role in the world. But today the political and security landscape has changed, and for the worse. Our success and our credibility in the world, and before our own citizens, rest in our ability to tackle challenges on our very doorstep. And we are being challenged in our own neighbourhood, both to the east and to the south.  Dear colleagues, the world has changed and the EU needs to have a strategy, a new European Security Strategy which clearly identifies objectives, instruments and partners. The new Vice-President/High Representative Mogherini has the determination and vision to lead the Union in the world. Before this House she acknowledged the importance of having this strategic, collective reflection. Let us not miss this opportunity. Our citizens and the world are watching.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. I would like to draw attention to the fact that, until now, farmers in my country, Poland, due to the EU bureaucratic mitre, have not received a single euro of the eu's much-heralded compensation for the Russian embargo on EU food. Unfortunately, only a small group of farmers, only a few thousand in Poland, will benefit from the funds launched in this year's budget. It is therefore necessary for the Commission to construct new proposals to compensate farmers for at least part of the losses in order for future compensation to go to all those affected by Russian sanctions. In this situation, I was very surprised to learn that the Commission wants nearly EUR 350 million from the so-called CAP crisis reserve to be allocated to the fight against Ebola in the 2015 budget. In my opinion, this is an irresponsible idea, since we know that in 2014 only a few farmers will receive compensation and Russian sanctions on EU food will also be maintained in 2015.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: Madam President, dear colleagues, regarding Catalonia, I would like to inform you and denounce certain intolerable facts happening over the last weeks. Following the will of the Catalan people to peacefully and democratically decide their political future, it has become commonplace for the Spanish establishment to compare the pro-independence movement with Nazism. This outrageous exercise of political criminalisation seems to have become a national sport in some Spanish media and political parties. The Spanish Government’s reaction has been non-existent. Nothing has been done to stop or condemn these attitudes. In this respect, the Spanish Government is not upholding the fundamental rights and values of the European Union, in particular those mentioned in Article 2 of the TEU. The Catalan people expect Europe to answer and react, condemning those who trivialise Nazism and violate fundamental European principles.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: Madam President, today I would like to talk about ELCOGAS, a project which is an example of industrial development. From a pioneering project to develop ecologically efficient technologies and leverage local resources to produce energy; of a project that was born with European help and which today, when it demonstrates its environmental and economic viability, will close because of the greed of electricity and the inoperability of regulators. Today I want to denounce the situation of ELCOGAS, on which more than 1 500 jobs depend, direct and indirect, in Puertollano, a Spanish industrial region hit by 34% unemployment. From a plant that will close and from which Europe dissents. If we really care about employment, if we really care about industry, if we are really concerned about development and clean energy - as we were told yesterday by this new Commission - I call on them to work together to prevent the benefits from being imposed on people again. Not at the close of ELCOGAS. ELCOGAS doesn't close!

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: Madam President, energy security is a cornerstone of the common European energy policy. While the risk of Russian gas dependency has been widely recognised, there has been much less discussion about nuclear investments. Furthermore, Russian energy companies are known to provide a means of influence for the Russian Government beyond mere business transactions. The Hungarian Government has agreed with Rosatom to build two new reactors and the Finnish Government has also taken a decision to cooperate with Rosatom on a new nuclear power plant.  These investments will strongly affect European energy security as they will strengthen the trap of technology dependency, link the European energy supply to a nuclear-fuel cycle largely dependent on Russian capacities, and make European energy supply more vulnerable through closer financial ties to the Russian State and companies’ integral links to it. Europe should take urgent action to deal with Member State decisions that threaten Europeʼs energy security.

name: Diane DODDS
text: Madam President, two weeks ago in my constituency of Northern Ireland, 900 employees of JTI Ballymena were told that they were to lose their jobs. Make no mistakes about it: these redundancies are the direct result of the revised Tobacco Products Directive. The backdoor deals thrashed out around minimum pouch weights and pack sizes were illogical and deeply damaging. I warned Parliament that jobs would be lost and, sadly, too many ignored this or simply did not care.  It would be perverse, therefore, for EU regional development funds to be used to attract these jobs to Eastern European economies. UK taxpayers already pay more into Europe than they get back out. They should not have to stand by while their own money is used to rob them of employment. These institutions, Madam President, must be in a state of readiness to help and aid the workers from JTI Ballymena.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: Madam President, growth under our 2020 Strategy has to be smart, sustainable and inclusive growth in the coming years. And that will only be possible if we are committed to inclusive education systems, policies that ensure widespread access to the ordinary centres of all students with special needs; to ensure that they stay in these centres on an equal footing with the rest; that also ensure the quality of the educational response they receive and, of their not, the promotion of all of them at different educational stages. They have to be in the ordinary classroom: students with special needs and students without special needs cannot be segregated. The temporary non-permanent schooling of this type of students has to be very exceptional. That is undoubtedly betting on educational quality—there is no educational quality without full inclusion—and it is betting on value education. Everyone brings something: the one who has a disability receives the encouragement of his companions; those who do not have a disability learn to be tolerant, the value of respect and tolerance.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Madam President, at this moment, state celebrations commemorating the Hungarian Revolution of 1956 began in Hungary. On our national holiday, it is not the atmosphere celebrating peaceful European democracy, but social exclusion, the fear of poverty, the desperation in Hungary because of everyday life. I would therefore like to draw attention to a general European problem. Hundreds of thousands of people from Hungary, nearly 600,000 young people of my age, have migrated to Western Europe, voting with their feet because of hungarian socioeconomic conditions and looking for their place, looking for their own opportunities to start a new family. I will not leave the Juncker Commission alone, I will draw attention to it every week, we need initiatives to help these young people return to their own homes and get on with their lives there. From here, I would like to thank Commissioner Laszlo Andor, the former Hungarian Commissioner, for his work on the Youth Guarantee programme, but there must be a continuation, a waiting programme for home.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Madam President! I would like to draw attention to the fact that in Germany the small credit institutions, the savings banks, the Raiffeisen funds, the cooperative banks are at risk from the banking union, are threatened by the supervisory mechanism and by the common resolution mechanism. This puts into question an important element of regional credit provision for small and medium-sized enterprises. Because banking supervision, with its excess of regulatory regulations, takes no account of the fact that small institutions are much less likely to take into account what is required of them there than is the case with large institutions. Moreover, there is a great preference for systemically important credit institutions in that there is an implicit government bailout guarantee that facilitates the refinancing conditions for large banks over those of small credit institutions. It is therefore unfair that small credit institutions should have to participate in the resolution fund in the same way as the large banks. I therefore call on Parliament to accommodate small credit institutions.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, as the Islamic State continues to advance, one of the biggest political crises of the early 21st century continues before our eyes in Iraq. Incidents along the Turkish border warn that jihadist expansion has reached the euro-Atlantic sphere of interest. Europe today is one of the greatest hopes of the persecuted. We in Central Europe, Hungary, have known since 1956 what it means to suffer a military aggression. Today, Iraqis, including most Christians, are fleeing and suffering martyrdom. Europe must not remain passive again for political reasons. Soon to be among us, Pope Francis called for real political engagement from the international community earlier this week. What can Europe do today? Aid organisations belonging to religious denominations are setting an example. One of them, "Aid to the Church in Need", spends millions of euros on the construction of accommodation as winter erstra. I repeat: Europe's responsibility is growing, Europe must save lives today, and our own citizens expect us to do the same.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: Madam President, many want a social Europe. For this we need low prices for agricultural support products, for transport, for machinery, everything to be able to induce competitiveness throughout the agricultural sector and a fair output in terms of production. Austerity policies have brought Romania a 24% VAT on all food products. The decrease in VAT on the entire bakery production line by 15% was a positive measure. The price of bread decreased by more than 10 %, tax evasion decreased by 20 % and production increased by the same percentage of 20 %. We have achieved savings of EUR 136 million in less than a year. The measure has demonstrated its benefits, both for citizens and for the industry. Such measures are beneficial for European agriculture. I believe that a detailed analysis by the Commission can serve as a conclusive argument for a broader fiscal policy at European Union level.

name: Georgios KYRTSOS
text: Madam President, the vote in favour of the Juncker Commission is good news for the Greek economy, because Mr Juncker has shown that he is a philhellene and has interesting ideas. But we must all move dynamically and effectively. Firstly, greece's government needs to be bolder when it comes to reforms. Secondly, the opposition parties in Greece must stop saying 'no' to everything - it is typical that they were more negative on Mr Juncker's case than their political groups in the European Parliament. Thirdly, there must be the Juncker investment programme of EUR 300 billion. And fourthly, the arrangement agreed for Greek public debt between the euro area and the Greek government must be made, an arrangement that will transfer payments from 30 to 50 years, so that the Greek economy can grow, but also get their money back in the long run. ,

name: Paul BRANNEN
text: Mr President, carbon capture and storage (CCS) can reduce the amount of CO2 in the atmosphere, thereby tackling climate change. CCS provides a medium-term future for gas and coal in Europe. CCS can capture carbon emissions from the production of steel, cement and fertiliser. CCS can provide jobs thereby pumping money into the European economy while at the same time pumping CO2 under the ground into safe storage. In this way we can buy the time we need to transition to renewable energy. I therefore strongly call on the Council meeting this week to make carbon capture and storage a vital, intrinsic and viable component of our new EU 2030 climate and energy action framework. Carbon capture and storage: capturing to store, storing to save, saving to prosper.

name: Seb DANCE
text: Madam President, in 1907 a farmer from Surrey named William Willets put forward a suggestion that is so simple, yet so effective, that it has since been copied in over 70 countries around the world, including in every single Member State of the European Union. The simple act of putting the clocks forward one hour during the lighter months reduces energy consumption, increases tourism and leisure potential and reduces overall accident rates. Since 1996, the European Union has harmonised the times at which Member States have put their clocks forward and back in order to eliminate the many confusions that used to arise.  I believe we should extend this period from seven to eight months, as has happened in the US and Canada, in so doing replicating the benefits that I have described for more of the year and harmonising with North American time zones at a time when transatlantic trade is on the agenda. I have asked the Commission if it will look into this and I hope to secure support from Members should any proposals be forthcoming.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Madam President, on 1 November 2013 two young Greek children, Giorgos Foudoulis and Manolis Kapelonis, were brutally murdered outside the offices of the Golden Dawn People's Association. One of them was my son, George Funoulis. On November 1st, one year is completed. The responsibility has been taken by far-left terrorists, who to this day remain elusive. The murder of my child was also the reason I decided to get involved in politics, and I'm here, among you. I want everyone to condemn terrorism wherever it comes from and 1 November to become a pan-European day against terrorism. Thank you. Immortals!

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: This item on the agenda is closed.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for debates on cases of violations of human rights, democracy and the rule of law (Article 135 of the Regulation), and first of all the debate on six motions for a resolution concerning the dissolution of the NGO Memorial (Sakharov Prize 2009) in Russia (2014/2903 (RSP).

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: author. - Madam President, the Russian Justice Ministry’s request to have the human and civil rights organisation Memorial closed down reflects just about all that is wrong with President Putin’s Russia. Memorial works to promote democracy, the rule of law, human rights and civil society activism – all principles that are being eroded currently in Russia. On a more symbolic level, it works to inform the public of Russia’s true history, exposing the terrible atrocities committed during the Stalinist Soviet era – a history that the political establishment more usually today glosses over and vaunts as a guiding light for the future of Russia. As Ukraine moves closer to parliamentary elections, we see the chaos that reigns across the regions of Donetsk and Luhansk as a result of the practical implementation of that kind of dogma. Memorial is just one organisation in Russia, but iconically it represents the Russia that should be and its closure is extremely worrying to us in this House.  Russia has, with China and Saudi Arabia, recently drafted proposals to the ITU to give control of the Internet to national governments and away from ICANN as part of a crackdown on Net freedom. Fortunately the USA, a lover of freedom, is blocking this and rightly so as the Net, for all its faults, remains a forum for free expression by the victims of authoritarian regimes globally.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: Author. - Madam President, the Russian Society for the Defence of Human Rights Memorial and the Ukrainian Maidan Movement are two pages of the same coin. Both are strongly anti-communist and anti-Slavic. Memorial helped demolish the great Soviet empire in the late 1980s. He demanded respect for human rights, and I am not dissuased to say that without memorial, the fall of the Soviet Union would have occurred much later. Maidan has made it clear that Ukrainians do not want to stick their heads back into the tufts of the new Soviet Union. Both memorial members and participants in the Maidan revolution have shown bravery and principled opposition to a regime that has violated human rights for nearly a century. We know well, ladies and gentlemen, that we who side with the Maidan have lost our battle for the Sakharov Prize for the Maidan in the European Parliament. Let me recall the words of one of Russia's most distinguished human rights defenders in decades, Sergei Kovaljov: "Defending human rights cannot be an internal matter of any state." Let's support Memorial!

name: Tamás MESZERICS
text: author. - Madam President, the facts of the case that this resolution speaks about are very clear. There is no point in reciting all the facts; we all know, those of us who sit here and who have been observing developments in Russia, that the actions by the Ministry of Justice and Putin’s governments against Memorial are basically a petty, malicious and vindictive response to the activities of Memorial.  The problem Putin’s government has with Memorial is not what it does, but what it stands for. What it stands for is the uncompromising and consistent denouncing of all the crimes of Stalinism, and it has been doing that since the 1980s.  Now, I was a student at that time and a few of my heroes were among the Memorial people who took enormous risks, personal risks, to commemorate the victims of Stalinism, some of whom are no longer with us. Memorial represents the continuity of that civilian courage, which Putin’s government is very much against, and this is very clear.  One more worrying sign is that, although this could be expected from Putin’s Russia, we are seeing some of the Members in this assembly may for this very reason not be able actually to sign this joint resolution. That is something we need to reflect upon.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: Author. Madam President, if there is one country on which the European Parliament has no shortage of emergency resolutions, it is Russia. It is true that the human rights situation is worrying, but it is much worse in many other countries, on which it is difficult to get a debate. I'm sorry, I'm sorry. It has been twelve years, for example, that we have not had a debate on the situation in Eritrea. Yes, Memorial is a remarkable association and a symbol of the repression of human rights defenders in Russia. Regular searches, confiscation of archives by the police, arrests, ransacking of premises and physical assaults, this is its daily lot, especially since the adoption of the law on foreign agents. Sad vocabulary. Today, it is threatened with dissolution. Other NGOs face the same fate, ordered to pay exorbitant fines that often force them to dissolve. I have signed this resolution and I will vote on it. But I am not sure that this is the best way to help human rights defenders in Russia. Mr Putin is not sensitive to this kind of message. At most, he is capable of healing his image, as he did at the time of the Sochi Olympics.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Author. - (DE) Madam President, I would like to thank The news that the Russian authorities are closing Memorial is extremely worrying, not only because it is an organisation that has been awarded the European Parliament's Sakharov Prize, and not just because it is part of the chain of similar measures. How a country stands on its past also says a lot about how it sees its future. Stalinism was an unimaginable crime against humanity. There is nothing to indicate. The rigorous reappraisal of one's own past is an important act of political hygiene. We have had this experience in the German-speaking countries, and we have benefited from it. This work of remembrance has paved the way for us to see the values of Western democracy as immovable. Facing the past is a sign of strength and an investment in the future.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: author. - Madam President, Putin’s aggression towards his neighbours requires urgent attention, but must never overshadow the human rights situation in Russia itself. Civil society, journalists and opposition figures are all repressed and intimidated and the Russian people live in an unfree free society, although propaganda suggests otherwise. Laws systematically undermine freedoms and give authorities greater unchecked powers. The closing of Memorial is more than symbolic. Its founder, Andrei Sakharov, inspired the name of our human rights award which was given to Memorial in 2009. We urge the scheduled law suit against them of 13 November to be recalled and to revoke all conspiracy-theory-driven foreign agent laws against NGOs.  The Government of the Russian Federation should at the very least adhere to agreements it has itself made in the context of the Council of Europe, the OSCE, the European Court of Human Rights and, of course, its own constitution. We see a clear difference between ill-guided Kremlin policies and the population of Russia, and we support their aspiration for a just, democratic and free Russia.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab 2014 should be the anniversary of the Memorial, because exactly 25 years have passed since the official inauguration of the association. We know very well that the activity started earlier and the achievements of this association are quite impressive. I would remind you that this is documenting, disseminating, promoting civil rights and good remembrance of victims, and this must inspire recognition and respect. In my opinion, russia itself owes the most to the Memorial, and it is a pity that Moscow does not understand and see this. It was the activities of such institutions that created the modest but important credibility of the Russian state itself. Completely incomprehensible are the threats of abandonment, obstruction or even liquidation of such a valuable activity with such valuable achievements. I would remind you that today's debate and the proposal for a resolution also stem from the conviction that the memorial's activities include not only Russian affairs, but also many other countries, especially societies and peoples. It is no coincidence that branches, individuals or even fairly autonomous institutions also operate outside Russia.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. The internal situation in Russia is of concern to international public opinion. Human rights defenders working for citizens are increasingly being persecuted there. The Memorial Association, honored not only with the European Parliament award by Im. Sakharov, but also with the Pro Dignitate Humana award by the Polish Ministry of Foreign Affairs, is another victim of the Russian Law on So-called Foreign Agents. Hundreds of NGOs have been subjected to unannounced inspections that have blocked their work, and dozens of them are now embroiled in lawsuits leading to excessive financial sanctions and, in some cases, closures. In this context, the restriction of the right to freedom of association of citizens must be strongly condemned. The authorities of the Russian Federation, in accordance with Russia's international human rights obligations, should take the necessary measures to repeal the Foreign Agents Act, thereby allowing civil society organisations, including the Memorial Association, to carry out their work.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Putin's Russia dissolves its conscience – initiated by A. Sakharov Memorial, winner of the European Sakharov Prize awarded by the European Parliament. This is a blow to the Russian anti-Putin opposition. For Polish, this is a deterioration in the chances of real Polish-Russian reconciliation. It is also another event confirming stalin's turn in Russian politics after the aggression against Georgia and Ukraine. This situation requires our adequate diplomatic, financial, economic response, but also a revision of the concept of partnership. It must not be the case that the European Parliament becomes a forum for humiliating speeches by Russian representatives, as in pcc councils.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Sakharov Prize for Freedom of Thought is intended to honour exceptional individuals who stand out for their fight against fanaticism and oppression such as Andrei Sakharov. The Russian human rights organization Memorial, which denounces political repression in the countries of the former Soviet Union, won the award in 2009. Russia's Ministry of Justice has asked the Supreme Court to wind up the historic NGO, which was nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize last year. Officially the reasons are 'technical' and concern the organizational structure of the organization, but these seem a pretext and without foundation. Memorial, in fact, today risks having to close as a result of the Law on Foreign Agents, a law according to which NGOs that receive funding from abroad and are active in the public sphere will have to register on a special register, the register of foreign agents precisely, in order to be authorized. Memorial has just come under the crosshairs of pro-government broadcaster NTV, which accused it of supporting extremists and terrorists. All this is a very serious attack on civil society. The European Union cannot remain silent in the face of these totally undemocratic actions.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I understand that your nightmare is vladimir putin, and I also understand that you are thinking according to where you are laying your butt. So why do we not talk about the cluster bombs that Ukraine has launched to Russian minorities? Because, for example, let us not say that Europe's foreign policy, basically NATO, is not what Europe does! Why do we not say that Russia is doing well economically and Europe is still getting worse and worse? Why do we not say that unemployment in Europe is getting worse and worse, there is no work, companies are closing down, there are so many bankruptcies and instead in other parts of the world things are working better? I would also like to remind you today that it is the birthday of a marò who is in India, Salvatore Girone. If instead of being kidnapped by the Indians, he had been kidnapped by Russia, a mess would have come out here. And instead, since they are the Indians, shut up and mute, because you are strong with the weak and weak with the strong! This is your system! So I tell you that you have to have more courage and not look to Putin as an enemy. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8))

name: Liisa JAAKONSAARI
text: blue card question. "I want to check if I heard you correctly. Did you say that the Russian economy is doing very well, and did you think that the European Parliament should remain silent about human rights violations in Russia? Did I hear you right?

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: Answer to a blue card question. You have understood correctly, I am saying just that: that Russia is an example for economics and development, Europe is the opposite example. That is what I have said and that is what I repeat. For me, Putin is a great leader, today Europe is also close to Africa for illegal immigrants, thanks to you. And human rights try to ask with cluster bombs what ukrainians did with Russian minorities. Aren't those human rights? Those are not human rights, throwing bombs at defenceless people, those are not human rights. Shame!

name: Tunne KELAM
text: Madam President, the request to shut down Russia’s most respectable civil rights organisation could be seen as an attack against just one NGO. It could also be seen as suppressing human rights and civil society as a whole, because Memorial has collected information about millions of victims of Soviet totalitarian terror. There must be something that is irritating Mr Putin’s regime. According to Orwell, he who controls the past can control the future, and he who controls the present – like Memorial – will control the past. Such action confirms only that the Russian Federation is not only the political but also the moral successor to the Soviet Empire, and that Kremlin rulers will see independent civil society as its most dangerous enemy. We should oppose such an approach and defend Memorial with all our forces.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: Madam President, in 2009 the European Parliament awarded the Sakharov Prize to Memorial for its contribution to the fight for human rights and democracy – core, non-negotiable values of the EU, and principles to which Russia, as a full member of the Council of Europe, the OECD and the UN, has committed itself. This House is deeply concerned about the action of the Russian authorities against independent human rights organisations and civil society groups. We all understand their essential role in today’s society and their universal value – no matter what the region, political system or culture. The time has come for the Moscow leadership to act responsibly and put an end to all acts of harassment, including at legal and judicial level, against Memorial and all other human rights defenders. Only a genuine and constructive commitment to shared values and principles on the part of the Russian Federation, a commitment without ambiguities, can help to restore EU-Russia relations.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: The efforts of the Russian Ministry of Justice to prevent the functioning of one of the most famous human rights organisations in Russia is a sad image of the current Russian regime. The apparatus of state power, which seeks to control society and silence independent organisations, is a step backwards towards totalitarianism. The state of democracy in Russia has long been problematic. Without the voice of independent civic organisations, society does not have the opportunity to reflect on its own. The memorial is precisely a symbol of the reflection that every healthy society needs. We in the European Parliament have awarded this organisation the Sakharov Prize and we have a duty to oppose what is happening to it. To do so, we will use our political weight and our political influence in supporting it and promoting the values for which we award this prize.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: Madam President, clearly the closing down of Memorial in Russia represents a threat to human rights, democratic values and liberties, civil rights and citizens’ rights, and should be condemned by all democratic countries. At the same time we can see what is going on nowadays in Russia, with what I would call Russia’s new imperial goals that are threatening our security in Europe. We have seen what happened with the seizing of the Crimean peninsula and what happened in eastern Ukraine and now we see that Russia has moved the challenge game to the Baltic Sea. I think all these actions should be thoroughly condemned by the European Union countries.  At the same time, we have all seen that Union negotiations have failed to provide gas to Ukraine this winter, and Russia is again using this energy weapon to have an influence on next Sunday’s elections in Ukraine.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: Madam President, this is a very sad moment for the country’s remaining democracy; it is a shameful part of the Kremlin’s policy and a grave reminder of the past history of Europe. Although we speak about one non-governmental organisation in Russia, the meaning is much broader. Our words reflect the deteriorating situation of political and civil rights in Russia. Sixty years ago, many in Europe were praising Stalin as a great leader. Now we hear, even in this House, many praising Putin as a great leader. Time will show, and I am sure that time will come very quickly. Colleagues, we have all been shocked by pictures of burning books in Crimea. Those books were declared dangerous to the official policy line. Colleagues, the 1930s are back to Europe. Totalitarianism is banging on Europe’s doors. Let us not be blind and deaf.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: Madam President, I was very amused to hear Mr Buonanno’s explanations and understanding of the prosperity of democracy in Russia.  I am really scared if he thinks we should forget the organisation to which we gave the Sakharov Prize. I do believe that we must not limit ourselves today by merely adopting a resolution, but should also concentrate on follow-up activities. There are not many means in our hands, but if each one of us were, for instance, to send an e-mail to that great democrat, Mr Putin, that might annoy him a bit.

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. In this room, we awarded the Sakharov Memorial Prize. Awarded for 25 years, the award bears the name of the man who contributed to the creation of the Memorial. At the same time, we know that two years ago, a law on foreign agents was adopted in Russia. This was not a good day for Russian democracy, because this law affects the Memorial at the moment, so the organization deserved even since the Soviet Union, which deals with historical research, the promotion of knowledge about the victims of Soviet repression, during the Stalinist period and not only, the protection of human rights in the countries of the former Soviet Union, but also in the present Russia, is to cease its action, We can not remain silent when we know that Russia is, after all, a signatory to the European Convention on Human Rights or the principles of the OSCE. Russia should respect these principles and allow the Memorial to function.

name: Marek JUREK
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. A few weeks ago, at the LIBE committee meeting, I called on the host representatives of the Council of Europe to respond to the persecution of the Memorial Association, because the attack on the Memorial is an attack on memory, an attack on historical truth. And this attack clearly confirms the neo-Soviet nature of Putin's politics. It is good that today we are talking about this in Parliament. The only question to be asked is why, in the resolution we will be voting on, there is again a provision in the Memorial on the political homosexual movement, the so-called LGBT movement. Such intrusive connections serve only Putin's propaganda. It is thanks to such inventiveness that Putin can present himself as an advocate of the moral order and act in this role against the tormented Russian people and against, as Lenin said, "useful idiots" in the West. Is it really about the authors of the resolution?

name: Marek JUREK
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, I note the near unanimity of support in all interventions for the resolution, with the exception of one solitary voice, but even though it is a solitary voice I think one should rebut certain strange arguments which are put forward in this Chamber. I could not believe my ears when Ms Jaakonsaari then wanted confirmation. Unsurprisingly, the confirmation came that what we heard was indeed true.  The argument runs as follows: the Russian economy is doing well – I have my doubts whether the Russian economy is doing well – therefore Russia has the right to dissolve human rights groups. Because this was the illogical consequence of the argument – that when the economy is doing well in any country in the world, it has the right to suppress human rights. I was not expecting this argument to be put forward in this Chamber, but it has been, and as some Members have said, it is good to rebut these arguments – and not just ignore them, because the moment we ignore them, the moment people make their intervention and then do not remain here to listen to the rebuttal of that argument, then that argument becomes credible. So it is a good thing that we fight this argument because what has been done to Memorial is not only damaging to Memorial itself in Russia, but to the entire civil society in Russia.  I would like to say what our High Representative has done, what the Commission has done. We have publicly expressed at the latest OSCE Permanent Council meeting last Thursday and also at the Council of Europe yesterday our firm conviction, as a Commission, that this decision is in contradiction with the very same international obligations which Russia has adhered to. It is not just the European Parliament condemning something politically, but that Russia is not adhering to its international legal obligations as regards human rights. To this end I remind this House, as this House has also publicly declared, that it has paid tribute to the courage of this organisation and awarded the 2009 Sakharov Prize to Memorial representatives, and that this was just a few months after the head of the Chechnya office, Natalya Estemirova, had been brutally murdered.  The steps taken by the justice ministry in Russia take place in the context of a shrinking space for civil society, with the Russian authorities attempting to weaken or suppress independent civil society organisations instead of empowering them. For the last two years, as this House knows, the so-called law on foreign agents has led many organisations, such as ADC Memorial and Golos, to close down completely in order to avoid further criminal prosecution of their leaders, and some activists have also fled Russia. So the Union will continue to be fair in reminding the Russian Government of its obligation to respect international human rights obligations and standards. Let me assure this House that whether or not we can resume our overdue human rights consultations with Russia, the Commission will keep on raising human rights issues with our Russian partners and keep a close eye on many individual cases of concern to us all. Furthermore, the Commission will continue to extend its support to independent civil society in Russia, which is crucial at this difficult moment.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place at the end of the debates. Posomné vyhlsenia (162)

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing – It is symbolic that, at a time when the European Parliament decides to award the Sakharov Prize for Freedom of Thought 2014, it is also fighting to preserve the existence of its 2009 laureate. Memorial's activities are under threat. A Supreme Court ruling on its existence will be handed down on November 13. In May this year, the organisation was asked by a Moscow court to register as a foreign agent for its "political activity" in the human rights field. Memorial, however, dissolution of its structure after this call, and although it continued to operate without registration, there is no legal basis for its abolition. Russia should consider whether the clerical error and registration of Memorial are more important than freedom of speech. The European Parliament believes that the main reason for the closure of the organisation is its activities in Ukraine and the promotion of Euromaidan. Russia is thus sending a signal to all of us that it is not in its interest to end the conflict there, but to silence the other side. It is extremely important to keep history in an undistorted form and to support all institutions that advocate preserving the memory of the nation. Therefore, let us, the countries of the former Communist bloc in particular, not forget, which meant encouragement to us from behind the Iron Curtain.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for debate on six motions for a resolution on human rights in Uzbekistan (2014/2904 (RSP)).

name: Seán KELLY
text: Údar. - A Uachtaráin, caithfidh mé a rá go raibh díospóireacht inár ngrúpa faoin ábhar seo aréir agus bhí meascán tuairimí ann. Cheap a lán daoine nach raibh Úisbéiceastáin inchurtha lena lán tíortha eile a mbímid ag caint fúthu sna díospóireachtaí cánacha seo. Mar shampla, tá dul chun cinn déanta acu maidir leis an bpionóis báis a chur ar ceal agus freisin dúradh go bhfuil an tuairisc seo ón Human Rights Watch ceithre bliana ar an bhfód. Foilsíodh é i mí na Nollag 2011. Bíodh sin mar atá, is ceart dúinn is dóigh liom féin díriú go háirithe ar choinníollacha ina bhfuil príosúnaigh pholaitiúla faoi láthair in Úisbéiceastáin agus brú a chur ar na húdaráis ansin cearta an duine agus cothrom na féinne a thabhairt dóibh agus go háirithe ós rud é go mbeidh cainteanna an mhí seo chugainn faoi, tá sé sin tábhachtach.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: Author. - (FI) Mr President, the Council decided to lift restrictions on arms exports to Uzbekistan a few years ago, in 2009 and 2010, precisely in view of the fact that this would be part of an attempt to open up uzbekistan and strengthen its human rights and democracy process. Now we can say that those of us who warned about this situation at the time were right. There has been no material improvement. This has been said many times by the UN human rights actors. Unfortunately, this is also evidenced by the fact that the Uzbek Government refuses to cooperate with numerous UN human rights actors. I believe that it is up to the European Parliament to raise the issue of the situation of political prisoners. As you can see, there is a somewhat exceptionally long list of names in this joint resolution, because we want to talk about people who are real people and who are suffering. The Uzbek Government is known for not wanting an international independent review of the Andizan massacre, which took place in 2005. We know that many of these political prisoners are still imprisoned for it. The Uzbek Government also refuses to discuss, for example, an end to torture. It is clear that we need to address this situation.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: Author. Madam President, Uzbekistan is an uncomplicated dictatorship, one of the most corrupt countries in the world, which knows how to attract the good graces of all. A rear base in the United States for Afghanistan, he now buys weapons in France, Germany or Great Britain and reuses them against the population. Mr Karimov also knows how to maintain good relations with Russia and China. The Uzbek people are the big loser who, fall of the Wall or not, has not seen much change. Thousands of people languish in prison; they have been ill-treated, tortured and awaiting trial, some of them, for more than twenty years. In this context, this resolution is welcome - there have not been one since 2007 - but it is very weak. That is why we did not sign it, not least because it was difficult to mention the issue of cotton, forced labour and the work of NGOs in this area. Again, there is a partnership, but it was barely damaged in 2005 when there were nearly a thousand deaths. Too bad! The Uzbek people are entitled to the same attention as the Russian people.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Author. - (DE) Madam President, I would like to thank Even in independence, Uzbekistan has failed to guarantee respect for human rights. The country was therefore also subject to international sanctions. These were repealed because the government promised improvements. Despite assertions to the contrary, however, human rights activists are still systematically threatened, the prisons are inhumanand and degrading, and the prisoners include political activists, journalists and intellectuals, women and men. Prisoners are tortured and mistreated – from food deprivation to sexual violence. Ten years after the tragic massacre in Andican, it is finally time for the country to keep its promises. We are happy to support the country in this. I believe that it is very important to hear this call from Europe.

name: Karol KARSKI
text: Author. - (C) Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur As the US Freedom House, also quoted in the resolution, pointed out in a June report, I quote that 'Russia plays a key role in the distribution of democracy in the post-Soviet zone'. Russia also serves as, and I quote, 'a model and inspiration for policies leading to the retreat of free institutions throughout Eurasia'. The situation is particularly bad in Uzbekistan, which, while seeking independence from Russia, does so at the expense of persecuting its own citizens. The aim of our resolution is to point out to the people and authorities of Uzbekistan that maintaining national independence does not serve to mimic russia's policy of persecuting, torturing and forcing its citizens into forced labour. The example of Polish and other countries that have successfully liberated themselves from moscow's zone of influence indicates that this can only be achieved by defending human and citizen rights from all means, that the national solidarity of post-Soviet countries can only be built if we are in solidarity with every persecuted person and with every exploited worker.

name: Javier NART
text: Author. - Madam President, what the resolution raises are very practical things: following the Council's agreement to give Uzbekistan time to implement absolutely necessary resolutions and after this Parliament's resolution of 15 December 2011, where it was found that none of the requirements that had been determined worked, and in accordance with the Cooperation Agreement with Uzbekistan, Article 2 of which explicitly speaks of respect for guarantees and human rights, paragraph 12 states that it has six months to implement resolutions which it has not wished to implement and which, otherwise, Article 2 shall apply in relation to Article 95 of the Agreement , which means the suspension of the same. This is a sufficiently radical measure and what the GUE/NGL Group colleague has noted is all set out in the Resolution of 15 December 2011. Let's not be so personalistic, let's look for the common rather than the individual, it's worth it.

name: Joachim ZELLER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We are, of course, in the debate on urgent motions on topical and burning issues of violation of civil and human rights. This is also the case with the other two resolutions as far as Mexico and Memorial are concerned. With the case of Uzbekistan, I think that we have already exchanged everything that is in the resolution, and we should have the debate. I am far from portraying Uzbekistan as a haven of civil freedom and human rights. However, what we have here in our resolution is a reaction to the Human Rights Watch report, and I find here, right down to the wording, the copy-paste procedure, that we adopt wording from this non-governmental organisation and incorporate them into our resolution. I do not think that should be our way of working. The debate on Uzbekistan must be held, but then in a different place and not when we exchange views on urgent issues relating to civil and human rights.

name: Ana GOMES
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, 10 years have passed since the massacre that killed hundreds of people in Andijão, without any independent investigation ever. Since then, hundreds of people have also been charged, tried and tortured over the Andijão massacre in closed procedures, violating the right to a fair trial and in accordance with international standards.  Some of the crimes committed are subject to universal jurisdiction and the Member States of the European Union also have a duty to investigate and prosecute them where possible.  Faced with this situation, in a country where there are thousands of political prisoners, where torture is common practice, forced labour and child labour are massively institutionalised, we have to press in the European Union. At least there are regular visits by UN and Red Cross bodies to prisons, and work with UN special rapporteurs to carry out basic reforms.  I visited Uzbekistan in 2011. At that time we were very dissatisfied with the European Union delegation, precisely because we were not even able to talk to true human rights activists. The European Union has a huge responsibility in Uzbekistan.

name: Bas BELDER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Madam President, the fundamental right of religious freedom – I have not heard that yet – is being flagrantly violated by the authorities in Uzbekistan in many ways. Four concrete examples, addressed to the Commission and the Council. 1) Private possession of Christian reading is prohibited and leads to lawsuits in the case of infringement. 2) Gatherings of individual Christians in residential homes are disrupted by brutal government action. 3) Professed Christians are fined excessively in Uzbekistan. 4) Seizure of property, even vacuum cleaners, of Uzbek Christians is the order of the day. Despite all these government chicans, Uzbek Christians continue to preach the gospel fearlessly. For this basic freedom, the confession of your faith, the EU must stand up equally fearlessly to the Uzbek government.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, the resolution's comments deserve to be taken into account in particular, in all circumstances. Indeed, nearing the withdrawal of allied forces in Afghanistan, it is to be feared that one of the next objectives of fanatical Islamism will be Uzbekistan, a country in which the standard of living of the population deteriorates continuously and alarmingly, and in which fanatical Islamism continues to advance. The regime's strength is the breeding ground in which an increasingly widespread culture of anti-system violence thrives. There is a certain danger of seeing Uzbekistan become another Chechnya, and the responsibility that this could happen lies, ladies and gentlemen, in the present political regime of Islam Karimov, whose advanced age and visible deterioration—not only of his person, but also of his surroundings—make fear of a problematic and in no peaceful transition. This is the other issue we must address soon, ladies and gentlemen.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: on the part of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, it is difficult not to see the problems of which there are many in Uzbekistan. Highlights include highly opaque elections, the harshly repressive advance of government power against the population, which is mainly justified by the need to defend against the dangers of terrorism and Islamic extremism, the problem of more independent information in the media, child labor, prison conditions. However, it is also necessary to point out some recent positive moments – the adoption of a ban on child labour, which is used in cotton collection, certain reform steps in the judiciary and prisons, the adoption in December 2013 of an effective law prohibiting torture, violence, inhumane and cruel degrading practices.  I cannot agree with both the EU's and the US's outward criticism of President Karimov, but there is clear evidence that they maintain very close contacts with him and other politicians. Uzbekistan is an example of a selective and biased approach. I cannot accept double standards in politics.

name: Alyn SMITH
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, Uzbekistan is very much a regular topic, no stranger to this House, but there is little sign that things in Uzbekistan are improving and, indeed, real evidence that individual states and the international community are turning a blind eye to flagrant abuses. Even recently we have heard from the International Labour Organization estimates that around about a million Uzbek adults and children have been pressed into forced labour within the cotton harvest, as well as flagrant abuses on the part of the regime.  Now this blind eye does go back a long way, and back in 2004 Craig Murray, who was the UK Ambassador to Uzbekistan at the time, uncovered evidence of a man who had been boiled to death by the regime for a refusal to give up his faith and pledge allegiance to the regime. This was verified by Glasgow University, but instead of applauding Mr Murray’s diligence the UK hounded him from office. This does go back a long way. So if the UK and the Member States will not take the lead, the EU is in a position to do so. We have cleaner hands than most, perhaps, and I would refer the Commissioner to point 11 within the resolution stating that the EU should take the lead and table a UN Human Rights Council resolution under Item 4 establishing a dedicated country-specific mechanism for Uzbekistan. That strikes me as a positive contribution to continue pressure on the regime. Much as there are few signs of light, we must stick close to our principles or else Uzbekistan could become a breeding ground for – as we have heard – anti-establishment and extremism, and we must stick true to our principles. I would be grateful for the Commissionerʼs view on that suggestion.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, if the force of the rule of law were proportional to the number of raw materials in a country, Uzbekistan would be a very fortunate nation. The flagship of the economy is cotton production second only to that of the United States, but based on the exploitation of almost a million children every year. Protesting in the country is a crime, not a right.  According to reports by Amnesty International and Human Rights Watch, access to independent international inspectors is completely banned in Uzbek prisons, and political dissidents, known as enemies of the state, are being subjected to unspeakable torture: beatings, attempts at asphyxiation by plastic bags, not to mention the use of electric shocks and rape and violence. Reporting torture can be very expensive, even a whole career. Former British Ambassador to Uzbekistan Craig Murray is well aware of this, and he discovered that as many as two dead opponents had been boiled alive. In 2005, the Andijan massacre took place. Sanctions were imposed that worked, prisoners were released, but they were lifted. Why do we always manage to do the opposite of what is right? Let us take our responsibilities!

name: Goffredo Maria BETTINI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, once again we as the European Union are faced with countries that we want to support in their development, and once again we must find that human rights, democracy and freedom are not respected in them. Despite the fact that the Uzbek authorities deny this, in Uzbekistan, after the 2005 massacre, the conditions of the rule of law are very bad, dozens of detainees are in prison for political reasons, the authorities are shruging their shoulders as if nothing had happened. We must make it very clear that if these violations do not end immediately, this cannot but have negative consequences in the negotiations between Uzbekistan and Europe on partnership and cooperation agreements. I stress and repeat, we must say this with great energy.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. If we want the European Parliament to play a real role on issues such as the protection of human rights, we must be clear and very precise. Mr Zeller said that this is not an urgent matter, but since we have already decided to address the issue of Uzbekistan – I understand that this was the decision of the Conference of Group Presidents – we should be talking about it very precisely.  I fully support the demand that the names of persecuted, imprisoned persons be included in an integral part of the resolution and, if this is not possible at the moment, they should be included in the letter from the President of the European Parliament to the Authorities of Uzbekistan. After all, these are very specific and dramatic issues such as the situation of political prisoners, torture and child slavery. A meeting of the European External Action Service with the Uzbek authorities will take place on 18 November. I expect it to be full of specifics, we will get a report on this meeting and that we will return to this issue in order to be systematic and precise.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: Madam President, speaking of Uzbekistan, I want you to have this image in your head: imagine that your sons or daughters when they are young are forced to work, to collect ten kilos of cotton a day in inhumane conditions. Imagine that when they grow up a little more, they fall victim to trafficking in human beings and are taken to other countries to practice prostitution. Imagine that if your daughters have been lucky enough to dodge that reality, before they reach adulthood they pass into the hands of men who have the right to beat them, despise them, and rape them. Imagine that if they have come out of all that, 80% of them when they give birth by C-section are then sterilized without their consent. This is all happening. And, as always, because of the economic and geostrategic interests, which are the ones behind it.  Let us also recall that the European Union has maintained an agreement with Uzbekistan on textile trade since 1995. In short, we demand — with the support of this House — that the European Union play the role it must play and be the guarantor of human rights.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, almost 10 years have passed since the massacre of hundreds of peaceful citizens, including women and children, by the Uzbek security forces. Almost 10 years have passed since the massacre in Andijan, and the perpetrators of that massacre still enjoy total impunity. In the Asian country, among the poorest in the world, activists, journalists and lawyers are systematically reduced to silence, by torture and large-scale violence. All this while in the West many countries prefer for strategic reasons to disregard what is happening.  A very tough relationship between 2009 and 2011 and published today by Human Rights Watch snootys data and testimonies that violations are systematic and torture a chronic problem, in a country where UN observers have been banned for more than a decade and investigations do not exist. The picture is among the most alarming in the world and the country can slip into dangerous isolation while torture remains routine for the government that continues to lie. The European Union must urge the entire international community to reconsider its commitment to a real improvement in the human rights situation in Uzbekistan.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: The situation in Uzbekistan is worrying, very worrying in terms of respect for human rights, although the Uzbek authorities have made serious commitments in this regard. I support my colleagues who initiated this resolution, and I believe that the Uzbek authorities must immediately release politicalprisoner prisoners, put an immediate and unconditional end to all forms of torture and abuse in prison and ill-treatment in pre-trial detention sites. Ensuring rapid access to adequate medical care for prisoners must be a priority. We must make every effort, ladies and gentlemen, and use all the tools at our disposal to get the Uzbec authorities to implement their commitments.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Madam Chairman, human rights have been violated so far, and as it stands they will continue to be violated, perhaps even worse and bloodier. What is the EU doing? He signs and sends various resolutions. If someone gets scared, then great. And if not, then nothing.  The conclusion from this debate should be that we will either threaten all those who brutally violate human rights with sanctions and then strictly enforce these sanctions or the people over whom violence is carried out honestly and fairly that we cannot or do not want to do anything and are on our own.

name: Herbert DORFMANN
text: Madam President! Yes, I wonder what this issue actually has to do under the topical and urgent debate chapter. When I read the resolution, we are talking about things that happened ten years ago. I know Uzbekistan relatively well, and I do not think anyone doubts that there are problems there in terms of human rights. But it would also be right for us to recognise in this resolution that the Uzbek Government is making every effort to make progress on many issues. It is, for example, the only country or one of the few countries in the region where the death penalty no longer exists. Even the UN recognises that progress is being made on the issue of child labour. They are trying to build a civil society, despite a problematic neighbourhood with Afghanistan. I think we should be critical of the country, but we should also try to move forward together with the Uzbek Government. This brings us more than here copy and paste to make a report of an NGO. I do not think that is worthy of a Parliament either.

name: Herbert DORFMANN
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, human rights issues are central to our relationship with Uzbekistan, and our policy as a Commission is twofold. We insist that Uzbekistan should comply with international human rights commitments but we also offer Uzbekistan, as some of you have said, our cooperation to promote reforms, to move ahead and to break away from its past authoritarian legacy.  The Commission is now pursuing this reform agenda at a very delicate juncture. Why? Because elections are approaching, the regional perception of violent radicalism is acute and a general suspicion about external interference is setting in. All this hardly creates the kind of enabling environment that would be conducive to quick and bold reforms. Moreover, there are many pending human rights issues which are of concern.  So I would like to inform the House that it must rest assured that the very issues highlighted in its resolution, such as the torture of detainees, arbitrary detention, major restrictions on the freedom of association, assembly, expression and religion, child and forced labour, are precisely those that the European Union has been raising on every occasion, including in high-level contexts and in our annual human rights dialogue.  Parliament can rest assured that the Commission will do it again in our next human rights dialogue set for this November, with the aim of achieving concrete results and in this context. Replying to the Honourable Mr Smith, the Commission will look into this issue which you address in paragraph 11 of the resolution. Rest assured that we shall really look into this issue. Today, I would like to emphasise one of the core issues at stake which were mentioned by some honourable Members, namely child and forced labour.
