Thanks to our insistence and facilitation efforts, constructive cooperation has now developed between Uzbekistan and the International Labour Organization and tangible results have already been achieved on child labour, while cooperation has also started on forced labour under a decent work country programme agreed with the ILO.  So we very much hope that Uzbekistan will take the same positive approach in other areas. We stand ready to cooperate with the Government of Uzbekistan in any efforts that it undertakes to ensure compliance with its international commitments and in the implementation of recommendations that it has already voluntarily accepted during the universal periodic review process at the United Nations Human Rights Council.  So, in conclusion, Madam President, our policy of constructive engagement aims to build on what has been achieved on child labour with a view to bringing about similar advances in other areas of concern. Of course, progress ultimately depends on the readiness of Uzbekistan to engage not just in reforms but in meaningful reforms.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place at the end of the debates. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. – The protection of human rights in Uzbekistan has to be guaranteed and effectively implemented by the Democratic State, under the International Conventions that the country itself has forced to comply with. Reports of arrests for the exercise of freedom of expression, child labour, arbitrariness and torture within uzbekistan's criminal and justice system are widely documented and are grounds for deep repudiation by the international community. I therefore consider it extremely important to adopt this motion and to ask the Council, the Commission and the EEAS to provide Parliament with a public assessment of the measures taken by the EU to pressure Uzbekistan to meet the human rights criteria. It also seems to me essential to the establishment, within the UN Human Rights Council, of a Monitoring Mechanism for Uzbekistan that can permanently monitor the human rights situation in this country. Finally, and as is requested by the report, I hope that at the next meeting in the framework of the EU-Uzbekistan Human Rights Dialogue planned for November there will be a clear impact on the results of the EU in addressing these issues.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: , in writing. – The situation in Uzbekistan is appalling. The use of child labour, the harassment and imprisonment of human rights activists, civil society members and journalists, and discrimination against minorities are unacceptable. It is not difficult to see from where Uzbekistan may take its example: from a strong regional player, namely Russia. There, too, the situation is a gloomy one that should leave no room for euphemisms or for denial about human rights abuses. Yet there are powerful EU countries which not only do not care, but which actually enable such behaviour. Ceterum censeo, France will seriously regret its decision to sell Mistral warships to Russia.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: Agenda calls for debate on six motions for resolution on the disappearance of 43 student teachers in Mexico (2014/2905 (RSP))

name: Teresa JIMÉNEZ-BECERRIL BARRIO
text: Author. - Madam President, my first words I want you to be, from the depths of my heart, solidarity with the Mexican people in the face of the barbarity of The Crimes of Iguala, and, of course and mainly, to support the victims and relatives of these inadmissible crimes. Right now, all Mexicans and Europeans who believe in human rights need to raise their voices and use it as the basis for true cooperation between distant regions in kilometers, but close in values. Not only do we have to raise that voice, outraged, with deep condemnation of these crimes, but we also have to offer our help to the Mexican authorities so that they can face the challenge of fighting drug trafficking and corruption, and against those people who use institutions for their own benefit, such as the mayor of Iguala. I welcome this decision by the Public Prosecutor's Office to capture them that we have been aware of: the climate of impunity that those who do not respect the institutions want to impose is enough. And I support dialogue and closeness to the Mexican people: only from it can we build and not destroy.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: Author. - Madam President, the enforced disappearance of these 43 students has caused shock in the world, but it is only the tip of the iceberg of a situation that we describe as impunity, and the data say so.  The country with the most murdered journalists in the world and 22,000 people missing, only half with the current government - and the government's own data say so. Or continued allegations of widespread harassment against social actors and political militants. Real impunity is also said by the National Commission on Human Rights. You don't usually judge, investigate, or sanction. Therefore, 98% of crimes go unpunished.  We don't need just good words, we need facts. Mexico must work together in the regional framework with CELAC to resolve this problem of widespread impunity, and the European Union Agreement must be conditional on the effective combat of this impunity.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Author. - (DE) Madam President, I would like to thank The case of the Mexican students who were killed or abducted on 26 September in the presence of the local police shows how important it is to keep an eye on the human rights situation in Mexico. While the country has made progress in recent years, this path must continue with much greater consistency. The relationship with Mexico will also be judged on this. Now, however, it is important to clarify the events completely and without consideration, not least out of respect and sympathy for the relatives. Knowing the full truth about what is going on is also an important prerequisite for a successful fight against the drug cartels, which willfully put people's lives at risk. They are the real enemies of Mexico and not the young people of Iguala.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: Author. - Madam President, no one misses that what happened these days in Mexico is extremely serious. I want to begin my speech by showing my sincere solidarity with the victims, the missing and their families. We want to denounce that this heinous crime adds to a climate of growing impunity in the country and we condemn the continued crime of enforced disappearances: more than 22,000 cases since 2006. We want to demand that the 43 living missing students be able to return with their families; we call on President Peña Nieto to end the climate of impunity by taking action for a serious investigation leading to condemnation; and we expect a relentless fight against organized crime from the Mexican government. I would like to express my group's sincere solidarity with the Mexican people in their fight against repression of social movements and against crimes committed by security forces. We call on the High Representative for decisive action in this regard, and we call for the modernization of the Comprehensive Agreement not to be contemplated until credible and tangible measures are taken to combat impunity. Ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, the Alternative Resolution and the amendments tabled by my Group of the United Left do not in any way seek to open a general case against a country we love. But loving Mexico and defending its people means today demanding more determined action against impunity.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: Author. - Madam President, I am deeply appmayed by the events in Mexico. Nearly a month has passed and the students, 43 young people from rural families, are still missing. This tragedy should never have happened. The events reveal the fragility of democracy in Mexico, despite the actions taken by the Government to ensure the safety of Mexicans.  We want students to return safely, and for those responsible for their abduction to be brought to justice, regardless of who they are.  We welcome the steps taken by President Peña Nieto and the Government to address this situation, but more needs to be done. This incident and the broader view emerging from uncontrolled links between local authorities and criminal groups are troubling. I hope that soon Mexicans will no longer have to endure this nightmare and that trust and faith in their local officials can be restored.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: on behalf of the PPE Club. – Madam President, I also want to express solidarity with the families of the missing students, but also with all the victims of violence in Mexico. We must also support efforts to shed light on this unheen case, including the efforts of the Mexican authorities. Mexico needs peace and needs a state of law.  Yes, it's outside the state of law when student organizations, so-called normalists, go to cut off roads, steal buses or attack businesses. But there's also a lot more out of the state of law corruption, murder, secret mass graves. So we also have to go into modernizing the global agreement precisely to help our friends in Mexico build that legal state and then be able to ensure both peace and prosperity for all citizens of Mexico. I think that's the message we have to send from the European Parliament today.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, students, colleagues of the missing, are with us today. On behalf of the European Socialists, I would like to give you a hug, show you our solidarity and tell you that this Parliament strongly, fully and absolutely condemns what has happened in the horrific crimes of Iguala. I want to tell you that we ask and demand that the Government of Mexico bring those responsible to justice—all direct and indirect. And we demand that there be no impunity. But at the same time, we tell the Government of Mexico that we want to work with it, that we do not want to impose sanctions on the Government of Mexico, on Mexico's democracy. We do not want to cut off our political dialogue in Europe with Mexico. We don't want to cut off our economic relations with Mexico. We want to help Mexico and we want the Government of this country to gain from these horrific events a new impetus to modernize, improve and give more democracy, more security and more freedom to the citizens of Mexico.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, 43 Mexican students from the Raúl Isidro Burgos teaching school in iguala disappeared on 26 September. I would like to express my solidarity with the families of these young people, who were taking part in a peaceful demonstration and who were violently repressed. Suspicions fall on some municipal police officers, the mayor of Iguala, as well as the paramilitary group Guerreros Unidos.  Ladies and gentlemen, since September 26, at least 10 mass graves and 28 bodies have appeared in Guerrero. Who are these victims? Can anyone say? Are we going to forget them? It turns out that since 2007, more than 100,000 people have died because of the violence caused by the drug business in Mexico.  The question I leave in the air is: how does the European Union want to boost strategic association with Mexico in order to help mitigate the country's enormous social asymmetries and what joint policies to combat global drug trafficking can develop, if, on the other hand, the Presidency of this Parliament refuses to send parliamentary delegations to that geographical area for dialogue with Latin American partners , which demonstrates a clear disinvestment in that region?

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: on the part of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, we are aware that the situation in Mexico is constantly deteriorating and it is more than necessary for the European Parliament to deal with it as well. In Mexico, repeated human rights violations continue to occur, drug cartels have a huge influence on the functioning of the country, more than half of Mexico's population lives below the poverty line, and the Mexican government is not seeing any effort to take steps to remedy it.  We express our deep solidarity with the missing students and their families and appeal to everyone that the situation needs to be addressed. Everything must be done not only to ensure that the missing students are found and that the perpetrators behind their disappearance are brought to justice and punished, but also to address the social and human rights violations in this area. It is necessary to ensure that in the future there is no such threat not only to young people in the world, but in general. The situation in Mexico shows that it is no longer possible to ignore the ever-widening gap between the poor and the rich, the increasing reports of disappeared people, and the plight of Mexico's justice system can no longer be tolerated.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: Madam President, it is shocking to me that we are discussing today a case in which peaceful protest students were shot, several of them killed and forty-three of them missing. It is shocking that the trial of this tragedy will take place on 23 October. On the day in 1956 the glorious revolution of the Hungarian nation, the Hungarian people, began. In these and subsequent days, such tragedies occurred in Hungary. Many students, workers, intellectuals gave their lives to the whole world in an example of freedom. On this day, symbolically, there is a delegation of 56 Hungarian students in the gallery, who came to Parliament with small Hungarian flags as an expression of their national pride, which was confiscated from them. Is there something wrong with human rights here in the European Union? I am now symbolically handing over a Hungarian flag to Madam President.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. I would like to support the text of the European Parliament resolution condemning the perpetrators of the kidnapping of 43 innocent students in Mexico. We are dealing with outrageous, painful acts of violence in guerrero state that cannot be accepted. Any suspicion of contacts with organised crime by local authorities should be thoroughly investigated, as there is no place in the rule of law for corruption and criminal contacts with the police. The increasingly violent actions of drug cartels and gangs that feel unpunished must be combated. Mexico is a key partner of the European Union, and I therefore call on the High Representative for Foreign Affairs to work closely with President Enrique Peña Nieto to clarify the matter as soon as possible, to punish those guilty and to repair the damage done to the victims and their families.

name: Liisa JAAKONSAARI
text: Mr President, fortunately, these tragic events in Mexico are now also known to the European Parliament and the world. That fine country has been caught in an almost unimaginable spiral of violence. Students disappear and people are killed. This is totally unacceptable!  In 2010, jyri Jaakkola and Bety Cariño, a Finnish human rights defender, were killed and this issue has still not been clarified, even though our ex-colleague Satu Hassi has tried hard, even on the ground, to influence the authorities. I believe that the European Union must now act and stand with the demonstrators who have been in front of this House and with the support of the entire Mexican people in the fight against violence, drug dictatorships, dictators and others.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: Madam President, the most special guests of this House are welcome: the colleagues of the 43 normalists of Iguala. Thank you for being here!  Today marks twenty-six days of his disappearance, proven to be ordered by the mayor of Iguala, currently in search and international capture with his wife. Iguala embodies all the evils that Mexico wants to conjure: violence, impunity and corruption, especially in public institutions. The Mexican state has to redefine the face of crime because it has made a dreadful qualitative leap. It's no longer just about complicity: public office, political representatives. In this case, a mayor is responsible for criminals; it is he who has given direct orders for persecution, killing and kidnapping, and that is very serious. Peña Nieto's government was slow to react, yes, and he missed badly by giving him local treatment at first. But it has been put at the forefront and its unquestionable defence of the rule of law, law enforcement and the persecution of the culprits must be recognised and supported by the European Union, which must also require the standards of transparency and accountability to end corruption.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Madam President! These are, of course, incredibly tragic stories that we hear from Mexico. Many colleagues have already discussed the issue here today. Our sympathies go out to the families and people affected. The people of Mexico are rightly in turmoil. But there are similarly tragic cases of human rights violations in Europe as well. That is why we should look, for example, at the events in Rotherham, England. What happened? In Rotherham, 1,400 young people, mostly girls, were raped between 1997 and 2013. These were mostly girls from socially weaker families. Some of them were poured with gasoline and forced into sexual acts. This has happened through men with Pakistani roots. And the authorities in the UK just haven't investigated. Why has nothing happened here? Why was it not investigated? I can tell you why: because the authorities were afraid of being confronted with accusations of racism. This is something that we should definitely put on the agenda.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Madam President, like my colleagues, I was shocked by the information about the massacre in Iguala. This tragic event must, of course, be fundamentally condemned by the European Parliament, but at the same time call on the Mexican Government to reform state institutions and continue the intensive fight against organised crime. However, it is not possible, in my opinion, to stay only with convictions. The European Parliament should look for solutions to help countries where organised crime is, at least in certain parts, over the head of the state. As a former Czech Minister of Justice, I am still reminded of how the EU has helped accession states with reforms of the judiciary and state institutions in general. I think that a similar form of assistance should be considered in the case of Mexico as the EU's strategic partner. I would therefore like to call on the appropriate Commissioners to pay attention to this area, to pay attention to the area of justice in countries such as Mexico.

name: Emmanouil GLEZOS
text: Madam President, all petitions, resolutions and actions against human rights violations, wherever they are made and by whoever they are made, are necessary and necessary. However, in order for all these actions to have value and power, we ourselves must prove in practice that we respect human rights. And the right to democracy, which is the most important of all human rights, is being violated here.  Yesterday, Juncker, that is, the European Union, proved the opposite of his insistence on imposing a Commissioner, even though the Committee on Culture had rejected him. But the European Parliament also tramples on the rights of MEPs and obliges them, when they want to submit an amendment, to have forty Members with the same opinion. Impossible.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, as an Austrian, I have great respect and affection for Mexico, its citizens and its citizens, for what they have achieved in history and for their ties to Europe. For example, I remember with great gratitude that Mexico was the first country to protest at the League of Nations in March 1938 against the Anschluss, the annexation of Austria by Hitler and his Nazi regime. With equal respect and affection I support, today, the Alternative Resolution in which we call for an end to impunity, not only in Iguala, but also for the case of Jyri Jaakkola, a Finnish citizen, and Bety Cariño, a Mexican citizen, who were murdered four years ago in Oaxaca. We call for the Government's words to translate into effectiveness and results so that the 43 students are released and that actual research comes to fruition. We also call for the global agreement not to be modernized until this is achieved.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, on behalf of Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, Catherine Ashton, I thank Members for this debate on the terrible incidents in Iguala in the state of Guerrero, Mexico. These appalling events, and the collusion between local authorities and criminal gangs which they have brought to light, have shocked Mexican society and the international community alike. We have seen a wave of public demonstrations over the incidents, which continue to this day. The events have also drawn unparalleled attention in the local and international media. From the very beginning, the EU delegation in Mexico and the European External Action Service (EEAS) have been in contact with the Mexican authorities, closely following developments. The EU delegation, in agreement with the heads of mission of the EU Member States present in Mexico, has expressed its profound concern over the crimes committed and called for an impartial and exhaustive investigation. Mexico is a close and valued strategic partner of the EU. The EU and Mexico have a strong convergence of views on human rights issues, both in multilateral human rights forums and also bilaterally. Mexico, belonging to the same group of like-minded partners as the EU, has been a strong supporter of many EU initiatives and resolutions in Geneva and in New York. Our regular High-Level Dialogue on Human Rights has allowed for several open and frank discussions on core human rights issues, including the fight against organised crime and reform of criminal justice. The international community should join forces with Mexico to support it in facing this difficult and complex challenge: the fight against organised crime and impunity. It is in this spirit that the EU supports the efforts of the federal government. Key issues in this endeavour are: strengthening the justice system, a reform of the police, reinforcing the culture of citizen security, and the observance of human rights. Human rights priorities for the EU in Mexico include the criminal justice system – and the issues of impunity, torture and arbitrary detention – as well as gender violence and threats against human rights defenders and vulnerable groups. These priorities guide the EU human rights dialogue and cooperation in Mexico. I would like to remind the House that through the Social Cohesion Laboratory II project, with an EU contribution of EUR 11 million, the EU supports capacity building at the level of federal institutions and in the states of Oaxaca and San Luis Potosi. Under the European Instrument for Human Rights and Non-State Actors thematic programme, the EU supports around 30 projects, including in the field of criminal justice reform, for an amount of EUR 7.5 million. In conclusion, we condemn the latest events with all our energy. The Mexican Government must carry out its investigations, bring the perpetrators of crime to justice and regain control of lawless areas.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place at the end of the debates. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Mr President, I should like to begin by thanking the – One hundred thousand dead in 6 years, 250 common pits full of corpses found in the last 2 years alone and about 27 thousand desaparecidos since the beginning of the war on drug cartels. It is not a war between continents, I am talking about greater Mexico, a country full of contradictions, bent by drug trafficking, corruption and anarchy. Today we are called to give a voice above all to the peasant parents of the very poor state of Guerrero, who between a thousand difficulties, between poverty and great social injustices for some time have lost the most precious thing that their children had! After the Tlatelolco massacre of 1968, when the army killed more than 300 student movement demonstrators in Mexico City, we are now facing the disappearance of 43 students, enrolled in one of the universities that symbolise revolutionary and civil struggle. When thousands of students and political dissidents in Argentina embarked on the "Vuelos de la muerte", Western public opinion tended to deny reality, although then, years later, they would be universally called "desaparecidos". The European Union must do everything in its power to demand an incisive and concrete commitment from the Mexican authorities, possibly threatening trade sanctions.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. – I support the resolution condemning the disappearance of 43 students from Magisterium since September 26 in the city of Iguala, Mexico. According to various sources, these students were persecuted and taken by police officers and handed over to armed men linked to a drug cartel. The mayor of Iguala, his wife and the city's police chief are on the run. In addition, 28 bodies that do not correspond to those of the missing students have been found in clandestine pits. These crimes call for a swift and firm response from the Mexican authorities. The current levels of infiltration of organized crime into local police and administrative agencies in certain areas of the country are alarming. The Mexican government has our full support to fight with determination against organized drug trafficking, police corruption and eradicate the climate of violence and impunity prevailing in some states of the country, in particular against activists committed to the promotion and defense of human rights. These crimes cannot go unpunished. Investigations must continue, those responsible must be identified and brought to justice

name: Tadeusz ZWIEFKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – This is not the first time that the European Parliament has expressed its concern about the escalation of violence and has spoken out strongly against trafficking in human beings as a result of drug cartels in Mexico. It seems that criminals in this country feel unpunished. Yet Mexico is a party to international human rights agreements and is a strategic partner of the European Union in terms of enhanced cooperation to achieve the highest possible standards in the area of the protection of freedom and individual rights. It is time to duly support the Mexican Government, which has shown a commitment to improving security in the country. The relevant agencies from the Union and Mexico should cooperate in the fight against organised crime and ensure that the rule of law prevails there. This democratic state and its citizens need our help, to ensure the protection of justice and respect for fundamental freedoms and human rights. On the other hand, in a case that has touched us so recently, there is a need for an impartial and comprehensive investigation. I am sure that it should be attended by independent international experts. Every effort must be made to identify, arrest and bring to justice the perpetrators of these offences. It is also our duty to provide all support to the victims of this tragedy and to their families.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: The next item is the vote. (For the results and other details of the vote: see Minutes) – Before the vote:

name: Jane COLLINS
text: Madam President, can you explain to me and my fellow MEPs why we have a known criminal, who has served time in Britain, wandering around Parliament quite freely? He should not be allowed to wander around Parliament. This is also a gentleman who turned a blind eye to the abuse of 1 400 children in one of my constituencies, and he is actually in the coffee bar, like a bad smell. I would like to know how that happened. His pass should be removed. His name is Denis MacShane.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: Ms Collins, we will bring this to the attention of the President of Parliament and we will look into it.

name: Teresa JIMÉNEZ-BECERRIL BARRIO
text: Madam President, I wanted to greet and thank you for the presence of the fellow students of Iguala (Mexico), who are here with us today in this rostrum. Before voting on this resolution, I wanted to give them our full support, as well as the relatives of the victims in Mexico. (Applause)

name: Marine LE PEN
text: Madam President, I am intervening under section 188 to ask for a referral to committee. The fast-track procedure, which was sought to be imposed on the commission, is clearly aimed at putting pressure on the electoral process to be held in Ukraine this weekend. To this end, a sloppy and indigent study was provided to the members of the committee on the consequences of these agreements on the European economy, which is already going so badly. This is unworthy of serious parliamentary work. We therefore ask that we refer to committee, so that we can analyse the risks to our economies under normal conditions.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: Ms Le Pen, for your request to be put to the vote you have to be supported by 40 MEPs. We are now counting. Apparently there are 40 so, colleagues, we have to take this into consideration in accordance with Rule 188. Before that we need a speaker in favour and a speaker against. Who wants to speak in favour of referring back to committee? Who wants to speak against referring back to committee? Thank you. Mr Landsbergis, as rapporteur you have the floor.

name: Gabrielius LANDSBERGIS
text: rapporteur. - Madam President, the main thing that has to be said here is please do not be fooled by Madam Le Pen and her constant ploy to destroy our reputation and that of the EP and the EU in general. This vote today proves that the EU can act swiftly and decisively. It has been made very clear to Ukrainians that we stand behind them and we understand the importance of this vote today. I call on colleagues to support the report. Ukraine needs us now. (Loud applause)

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Madam President! I expressly did not vote in favour of referral back to committee because I reject Mrs Le Pen's political objectives. I am in favour of free trade. I am also in favour of trade liberalisation with regard to Ukraine in principle. But I would like to draw attention to .... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: That concludes the vote.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Madam President! How can we help a country in economic difficulties, where we see the danger of these economic difficulties jeopardising social and democratic transformation? You help this country by reaching out to it for economic relations, by expanding and building economic contacts. That is what this motion says. We should give Ukraine a chance. We should give the economy a chance. We should also improve and facilitate economic relations with the European Union. Trade relations, tariffs and other things are simply part of it. I would therefore like to interpret the other way around as some of my fellow Members, as the small minority in this House: precisely in order to give Ukraine a chance, we must facilitate economic and trade relations between Ukraine and the European Union.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: Madam President, I was astonished by the number of people in this Chamber who are now prepared to act directly as cat’s paws for Vladimir Putin while calling themselves patriots, calling themselves even nationalists in their home countries. There seems to have been a strange ‘my enemy’s enemy is my friend’ reasoning that has led people into alliance and to become apologists for an organisation, or an ideology, which happens to be against the EU. Well, I think the European Union is an undemocratic racket, but that is not what is at issue in Ukraine. What is at issue there is the yearning of people to live in a normal country where property rights are respected, where contracts are honoured, where there is a pluralist multi-party system and where the individual is free of state control. You can support that system with or without supporting the European Union. My kind of euroscepticism is internationalist, cosmopolitan, open, warm and optimistic and it has no space in it for sympathy for Putinism.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Madam President! I did not take part in the vote now because you did not allow me to speak when I raised a point of order. The Rules of Procedure provide in Rule 41(1) that Parliament must determine the financial consequences of a legal act. The financial impact of this act has not been quantified. The parliamentarians did not even know what the financial effects were. The Commission's proposal does not include any quantification of the suspected financial shortfalls for the European Union. The rapporteur's report does not state the financial implications for the European Union of the owithly, as a way of waiving customs revenue. I have a right to raise a point of order, and you have curtailed that right, Madam President. That was not right. You have not complied with your duties as President, and you have prevented the European Parliament from taking note of the fact that it is taking a decision without even knowing the financial implications of that decision.

name: Bas BELDER
text: Written. - I support the extension of trade benefits for Ukraine, especially in the light of the current political situation in Ukraine; However, I object to the duty-free import of battery eggs from third countries to the EU. Battery cages are no longer allowed in the EU; it is undesirable and unsan time to explain that the EU should allow and encourage the import of battery eggs from third countries to the EU.

name: Ivo BELET
text: Written. - The extension of the tariff favour scheme for Ukraine pending the entry into force of the Free Trade Agreement with Ukraine is a major support for the hard-hit Ukrainian economy. At the same time, however, it is necessary for the European Commission, when importing food products, animal welfare and food safety, not to lose sight of it and to ensure that the breeding, production and slaughter conditions in force in Ukraine are adapted to the standards in force in the EU. This is also of great importance to European producers who have invested heavily to bring their products into line with these standards.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report, which aims to amend Regulation (EU) 374/2014, aims to reduce or eliminate tariffs on goods originating in Ukraine. After the negotiation of an association agreement between 2007 and 2011 between the EU and Ukraine on the creation of a free trade area and its signing on 27 June, the report should extend the regulation passed until 31 December 2015.  At a time when Ukraine is experiencing significant tensions, the current EU policy can only lead to a deterioration of our relations with Russia. The report states that according to statistics, Ukraine's exports to the EU increased sharply at the beginning of 2014 (up 25% or USD 587 million) at the same time as those to Russia declined (-24.5% or USD 592 million).  The report highlights the opportunity for Ukraine, through these trade measures, to diversify its markets and encourage its adaptation to the standards required in the EU, prior to the total free trade agreement in 2016.  In the face of the economic crisis we are experiencing, however, the reason would be that we refuse this agreement both from a political point of view (our relations with Russia are likely to deteriorate) and from an economic point of view (total open borders and free trade have caused only relocations, unemployment and deindustrialization in Western European countries).  That's why I voted against it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. - The one for the renewal of trade preferences for products from Ukraine is a measure that potentially harms many economic sectors of our country and for this reason I voted against its adoption.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this report because it supports the Commission's proposal to extend provisional measures to reduce or abolish customs duties on goods originating in Ukraine until the date of entry into force of the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement. This step is necessary as the planned entry into force of the said agreement on 1 November 2014 will not be due to a joint decision by EU ministers to postpone the entry into force of the Association Agreement until 31 December 2015 and to continue to apply the EU autonomous trade instruments in the interest of Ukraine during this period.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. - The European Parliament has taken the irresponsible decision to strengthen trade relations between the European Union and Ukraine. Indeed, the policy of economic association with Ukraine, as it is carried out today, has the direct consequence of the deterioration of relations between the Member States of the Union and Russia. France has no economic or political interest in maintaining a climate of cold war desired by NATO. Worse, while we see everywhere that the enlargement of the Union to the Eastern countries has created unfair competition between workers and caused massive relocations to these countries, the European Parliament proposes to continue this suicidal policy by extending the application of Regulation (EU) 374/2014 on the reduction or elimination of tariffs on goods originating in Ukraine, a country whose average monthly wage is just US$292! This reduction in tariffs will mean even more job losses and unemployment for our compatriots.  That is why I voted against the extension of this regulation.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. - I voted against. Politically wrong measure and harmful to the Italian economy. I would have preferred the measure to have been given the green light by the WTO, as was done with regard to trade preferences for Pakistan. The EU's anti-Russian obsession is not acceptable.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. - Extension of the period of application of Regulation (EU) No 1493/1999 374/2014 by the end of 2015 it is important to maintain a high level of support for Ukraine and to increase the safety of trade conditions. Autonomous trade measures will encourage Ukrainian producers and businesses to direct their exports to the European market rather than to the increasingly restrictive Russian market. European engagement in this accelerated process also provides Ukraine with an incentive to adapt its functioning and trade standards to those of the EU and to prepare for the full implementation of the DCFTA from 1 January 2016 at the latest. I support this.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - The recent political crisis in Ukraine is one of the priority points addressed by the EU in recent months. The proposal that was voted on and voted on is part of a package of proposals aimed at providing economic and financial support to Ukraine and supporting the country's economic stabilisation and structural reform programme.  These objectives can also be achieved by the reduction or temporary elimination of customs duties on the basis of a list of concessions contained in an annex to the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement.  This measure is not only intended to be an expression of the EU's solidarity with the Ukrainian people, but also shows that the EU is determined to take immediate measures to improve the situation of its eastern neighbours and that it has the capacity to do so.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. - Ukraine is a priority partner country under the European Neighbourhood Policy and the Eastern Partnership.  Regulation No 374/2014 on the reduction or elimination of customs duties on goods originating in Ukraine entered into force on 23 April 2014 and is intended to be in force until 1 November 2014. On 12 September 2014, the EU decided to propose to its Member States the extension of the agreement until 31 December 2015, maintaining the EU Autonomous Trade Measures for ukraine during that period. In order to support Ukraine in the extremely difficult political, economic and security situation, I support the extension of the EU's agreement with Ukraine, as well as support the introduction of the human rights clause providing for the suspension or cancellation of this agreement in the event of ukraine's non-compliance with the democratic principles of human rights, fundamental freedoms and the principle of the rule of law. This solution is part of a global peace process for Ukraine, respecting the territorial integrity of the country, as well as its right to decide its own destiny.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the resolution on customs duties on goods from Ukraine, because I believe that this resolution is of enormous geopolitical importance, as it is crucial for the peace process in Ukraine, which has been torn apart for months by war and external threats, for the establishment of a democratic government. I think it is right that the European Union has made a commitment with the Ukrainian Republic to extend tariff concessions for goods from Ukraine itself until 31 December 2015, that is, when the Association Agreement with the related obligations to Ukraine comes into force. I believe it is necessary for the EU to extend the economic and trade partnership agreements with new countries, without neglecting the importance within the political and economic chessboard for the European Union of the Russian Federation.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this proposal because it follows on from a previous vote in favour of the implementation of the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement. However, the EU must see that European food standards are assured and that any negative impact on European industry is addressed.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. - EU Regulation No 374/2014 on the reduction or abolition of customs duties on goods originating in Ukraine was to be applied until the entry into force or provisional application of the Association Agreement and no later than 1 November 2014. On 12 September 2014, the European Union agreed to propose to EU Member States, as part of a comprehensive peace process in Ukraine, to extend until 31 December 2015 the provisional application of the Comprehensive and In-Depth Free Trade Agreement while maintaining autonomous EU trade measures in favour of Ukraine during the period in question.  Since the regulation provides for unilateral preferences to be imposed on the Community budget by EUR 487 million, given the serious situation facing the Ukrainians, I believe that the best vote is abstention.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. - From the outing point we condemn and reiterate our condemnation of the coup d'éerous in Ukraine and the rise of fascist forces to the government. That is why we voted against the EU-Ukraine partnership agreement, as it was the trigger for the coup d'eer, and because the consequences of the free trade agreement will be disastrous for various sectors of the economy by both Ukrainian and some EU countries. Following the EU's alleged support for Ukraine, the imposition of the liberalisation of the economy, deregulation and privatization of various sectors, as well as the dismantling of the Ukrainian productive fabric, which will not have a position to compete with large European companies, is hidden. This report aims, in particular, to accompany the entry into force of trade provisions of the EU-Ukraine partnership agreement. That's why I didn't vote for it.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report by the Committee on International Trade as I agree with the proposed extension of the preferential trade regime with Ukraine. Since May 2014, Ukrainian exports to the EU have come under a preferential trade regime, which was granted by the EU unilaterally as part of a wider package to help Ukraine. At the outset, it was agreed that the unilateral measures would be valid for six months until the Association Agreement and its trade part (the deep and comprehensive free trade agreement) were signed and applied. However, because, while the Association Agreement has been signed, its application is suspended for the time being, we need to move with the adoption of an extension, as the original agreement expires on the 2 November 2014.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of amending the regulation on customs duties on goods from Ukraine, which extends for a further year the trade preferences currently in force with regard to Kiev. The regulation has the important objective of ensuring continuity and certainty in our bilateral trade relations at a very delicate political stage and with a view to the full implementation of the Free Trade Agreement (DCFTA), an important pillar of the broader association agreement with Ukraine recently signed. I consider it particularly significant that - including in this bridging regulation - a clause on respect for human rights, the rule of law and respect for the principle of sovereignty and territorial integrity, which is binding on the EU to grant trade preferences, is particularly significant. It is also important that particular attention be paid in the regulation to the most sensitive products, such as those in the EU's agricultural and agro-industrial sector, thanks to precise tariff quotas: this will avoid further penalties for the European agricultural sector, which has already been severely affected by the recent trade sanctions decided by Moscow. With the adoption of this regulation, therefore, we will be able to go down another stretch of road together in the difficult process of rapprochement between the European Union and Ukraine.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. - This text aims to help Ukraine cope with the political, economic and security crisis that Ukraine is experiencing. It will, in fact, eliminate or reduce tariffs on goods originating in Ukraine and thus support its foreign trade. Moreover, in the current context, Parliament's swift approval proves that the Union is capable of acting swiftly and resolutely while respecting its political commitments.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. After several months of political crisis aggravated by the conflict in the east of its territory, Ukraine is experiencing a dramatic economic situation. It therefore is in desperate need of the help of the European Union. Until the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement comes into force in January 2016, the EU must continue to grant tariff preferences to Ukrainian products exported to the European market. These unilateral trade preferences remove 94.7% of EU tariffs on imports of industrial goods from Ukraine. They also remove EU tariffs on more than 80% of Ukrainian agricultural exports. However, the EU has restricted zero-right amounts of "sensitive" products, such as cereals, pork, beef, poultry and processed foods, so that they do not harm the interests of European producers. In return, Ukraine is obliged to respect EU health standards, as well as human rights, fundamental freedoms and the rule of law. This process aims to enable the country to modernize, reform and actively fight corruption. The broad victory of the pro-Western Ukrainian parties in the parliamentary elections is, from this point of view, a guarantee.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. - The European Union has been participating in a comprehensive peace process for Ukraine, of which the commercial aspect is part and, more specifically, the reduction or elimination of customs duties on goods originating in ukraine. The extension of autonomous trade measures remains one of the most effective measures as statistics show: in the first half of 2014, ukraine's exports to the EU have increased significantly, with ukraine's exports to Russia reduced due to trade restrictions on goods from Ukraine wishing to access the Russian market and its unpredictability. The increase is around EUR 587 million, which, coupled with other factors, proves that THE MCA are undoubtedly among the possibilities that ukrainian producers and companies have to seek new markets and reduce the negative consequences of Russian trade measures of retaliation against Ukraine. MCAs also act as an incentive to adapt their way of working and their standards to the EU.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - We stand in solidarity with the Ukrainian people. That is why we have called for the coup d'état and the rise to power of a government that integrates forces of an assumedfascist nature. For this reason too, we voted against the free trade agreement which could prove disastrous for various sectors of the Ukrainian economy, in addition to the economy of several EU countries, Portugal included. The alleged help that the EU wants to give to the people of Ukraine we also know in Portugal. In exchange for financial aid, the EU will impose the liberalisation of the economy; the deregulation and privatisation of various sectors; the dismantling of the productive apparatus of that country, which is unable to compete with the major European companies.  What the EU wants is not to help. It just wants to extend its market to new consumers and have access to its raw materials. This report specifically proposes to postpone the entry into force of the trade provisions of the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement. Hence our abstention.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing - Ukraine must be given assistance and support in its extremely difficult political, economic and economic situation. One such measure on the part of the European Union is that the Member States of the European Union will temporarily postpone the application of the DCFTA until 31 December 2015, but during this period autonomous trade measures will continue to apply in favour of Ukraine. On the other hand, we must ensure that our European consumer is protected in the same way. The extension of the application of the regulation in question appears to be the best possible route, also taking into account the fact that exports from Ukraine to the Member States of the European Union increased significantly in the first half of 2014.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. - (IT) I wholeheartedly vote against renewing trade preferences for products from Ukraine. The measure has been subject to political pressure which does not take account of technical and commercial aspects.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. - I am voting against the EU-Ukraine customs union agreement because it was the reason for the coup d'état in Ukraine. It is a move clearly against Russia on a symbolic level, and I also believe that it will be detrimental to the Ukrainian people, based on the experience of my own people.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the Landsbergis Report on Customs duties on goods originating in Ukraine because I believe it is vital that we prolong the autonomous trade preferences granted to Kiev in order to avoid the creation of a legal vacuum for Ukrainian exports to the EU. In the current context, it is crucial that we do not diminish support to Ukraine, a close neighbour whose security, stability and prosperity is directly tied to ours.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the reduction or elimination of customs duties on goods originating in Ukraine, because I support a reorientation of Ukrainian businesses from the Russian to the European market. I see this as an opportunity to help stabilise the economy and politics in Ukraine while, at the same time, showing our respect and support for the European choice made by its people.

name: Eduard-Raul HELLVIG
text: in writing. - I believe that facilitating exports from Ukraine is a moral, political and geostrategic imperative for the European Union. It is not natural that, in the context of the chronicling of the Ukrainian crisis, we should question the economic impact of the increase in Ukraine's exports – and not just because of the asymmetry in this partnership. Russia's retaliatory measures, armed conflict and the occupation of part of Ukrainian territory by terrorist-separatist groups have severely disrupted Ukraine's society and economy, affecting production and living standards. Supporting Ukraine's efforts to overcome this critical situation is tantamount to supporting its legitimate aspiration to integrate into the European economic and democratic space. The increase in Ukraine's exports to the EU in the first half of 2014 by 25% is an encouraging indicator of this. The abolition or, where appropriate, reduction of customs duties on goods originating in Ukraine – in particular agri-food products – should be followed by new steps towards the creation of a deep and comprehensive free trade area, in accordance with the Association Agreement of 27 June 2014.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. - I voted in favour of the resolution. To those who abstain from this vote, or even to vote against, I would like to say that this is not a decision against Russia, but one for free trade with Ukraine. Where do we get to if we are to be dictated by President Putin with whom we trade and under what terms?

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: In writing. - I voted in favour of extending the lifting of customs barriers for Ukrainian exports to the European Union until the end of 2015. This exceptional measure responds to the exceptional nature of the situation in Ukraine. The Union has a moral duty to this partner, which is under immeasurable pressure from Russia in the economic, military and energy sectors. While these measures have, according to early estimates, kept the activities of Ukrainian businesses and industries afloat, with an increase in exports of between 10 and 25% in the first part of the year, they must not create the conditions for unfair competition with our own companies and further burden European farmers. On this last point, I will be adamant and if I see that our support is jeopardising the commercial activities of European businesses, industries and agriculture, I will again consider these measures in the direction of a rebalancing.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. - I voted in, because Ukraine is a priority partner country within the European Neighbourhood Policy and the Eastern Partnerships, and the amendment of the Regulation in question, which provides for the reduction or abolition of tariffs on goods originating in Ukraine, meets and assists the country in view of the extremely difficult economic and social situation it faces.  Exports from Ukraine to EU countries increased significantly in the first half of 2014, with the apparent consequence of a drop in exports to Russia, and fuelled the certainty of mutual trade conditions. Through these measures, but also for many others, the European Union demonstrates that it supports and supports countries of the European continent that respect the democratic principles of the legal state, promote respect for human and fundamental rights, and support the sovereignty and territorial integrity of national states.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of Gabrielius Landsbergis' report on tariffs on goods originating in Ukraine. The measures adopted will relieve the burden of Russian sanctions on the Ukrainian economy.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of amending Regulation (EU) No 374/2014 on the reduction or elimination of customs duties on goods originating in Ukraine. This transitional solution for allowing goods from Ukraine into European markets on favourable terms is the least we can do in the current situation. The amendment of the regulation is needed, as it would otherwise have ceased to apply as of 1 November 2014. Nevertheless, I find it regrettable that this procedure should be needed, as instead we should have immediately and fully implemented the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement and deep and comprehensive free trade agreement. The signal we are sending politically is like offering a quarter of a carrot. I urge the Commission and the Member States to provide all necessary assistance for speeding up reforms and building up a strong and viable Ukraine.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. - I supported the report as, given the current situation in Ukraine, a timely approval to prolong the regulation granting autonomous trade measures for Ukraine is necessary. It proves that the EU can act swiftly and decisively and signals our political will to help the Ukrainian people.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of Mr Beazley's proposal. Gabrielius Landsbergis because I believe it is important to support Ukraine in view of the extremely difficult situation it is experiencing, not only politically, but also economically. This EU decision, which will be based on the reduction or elimination of customs duties, shows that there is concrete action that is expressed through the adoption of immediate measures with the aim of making the conditions of non-European countries close to the EU better.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. - From the outing point we condemn and reiterate our condemnation of the coup d'éerous in Ukraine and the rise of fascist forces to the government. That is why we voted against the EU-Ukraine partnership agreement, as it was the trigger for the coup d'eer, and because the consequences of the free trade agreement will be disastrous for various sectors of the economy by both Ukrainian and some EU countries.  Following the EU's alleged support for Ukraine, the imposition of the liberalisation of the economy, deregulation and privatization of various sectors, as well as the dismantling of the Ukrainian productive fabric, which will not have a position to compete with large European companies, is hidden. This report aims, in particular, to accompany the entry into force of trade provisions of the EU-Ukraine partnership agreement. That's why I didn't vote for it.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. - The regulation on the reduction or elimination of duties on goods originating in Ukraine should have ceased to apply by 1 November 2014 at the latest. However, in order to support political and economic stability in Ukraine, the European Commission has proposed extending the application until 31 December 2015. The Commission proposes to extend the application of the Regulation to ensure that the Agreement covers the period from 1 November 2014 to 31 December 2015. The Proposal of the European Commission is as follows: -extension of autonomous trade preferences until 31 December 2015 - introduce a human rights clause allowing the suspension or cessation of preferences in case of non-compliance with democratic principles, human rights and fundamental freedoms and principles of the rule of law - ensure retroactive application of the extension of the Agreement from 2 November 2014. The Association Agreement with Ukraine ensures respect for democratic principles, human rights and fundamental freedoms, as well as respect for the principles of the rule of law, then promoting respect for the principles of sovereignty and territorial integrity, border protection, as well as combating the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction and fully supporting it.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. - Despite the difficult situation in Ukraine, it is important to support the entry of Ukrainian business into Europe, as well as the entry of european union business and goods into the Ukrainian market. Although it is an interim decision, it is also important. When people trade, they don't hang. I voted in favour.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. – I welcome this report in the current situation. The timely and rapid approval by Parliament of the Commission proposal to extend the regulation granting autonomous trade measures (ATMs) for Ukraine will prove that the EU can act swiftly and decisively and can fulfil its political commitments.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. - (IT) My decision to vote in favour of Mr Sulin's report stems from the awareness that we must support Ukraine in its situation of extreme political, economic and social difficulty while at the same time strengthening the certainty of trade conditions for economic operators.  A rapid and timely approval by the European Parliament of the Commission's proposal for the renewal of the regulation on the granting of ATMs to Ukraine will prove that the EU intends to act quickly and decisively to honour its political commitments.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. - I have today rejected the reduction or abolition of tariffs on goods originating in Ukraine, because not only are there important foreign policy reasons, but there are also economic concerns. These include the fact that Russia and its customs union are currently the largest buyer of Ukrainian exports. However, Russia will impose an import duty of 7.8% on 98% of Ukrainian products in order to protect its own market from the flood of European products. This is estimated to result in a loss of €165 billion for Ukraine over the next ten years. In addition, Ukraine will have to make an enormous financial effort to enable its companies to become competitive on the European market and thus to become competitive, since the DCFTA not only allows duty-free access to the internal market, but also requires compliance with European standards in this regard.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. This text is a continuation of the desire of the European authorities to integrate Ukraine economically, forcing it to make the absurd choice of development prospects with the EU countries at the expense of its main external market, Russia, with which it is de facto united by strong cultural ties. With the implementation of the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement postponed until 31 December 2015, the Commission is proposing to extend the EU regulation on lowering tariffs on EU-Ukraine trade to end on 1 November 2014. Being opposed to this association agreement which was the trigger of the Ukrainian crisis, I vote against it. Moreover, it is conditional on Ukraine's respect for fundamental principles related to human rights, democracy and the rule of law. However, these conditions are clearly not respected in Ukraine: the use of cluster munitions banned in civilian areas, procedures for banning the Communist Party, banning the broadcasting of certain television channels, censorship laws, the presence of neo-Nazis in the government. I am therefore surprised that such a proposal is being submitted to us.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. - We have approved here today the extension of the exemption from customs duties on products from Ukraine until the end of 2015. This extension will allow Ukrainian products to continue to benefit from a preferential regime to enter the EU.  In April, a regulation that reduces or eliminates customs duties on goods originating in Ukraine had entered into force. This measure was adopted with the aim of supporting political and economic stability in Ukraine and would have a six-month term, expiring when the trade provisions of the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement entered into force. As the EU and Ukraine decided on 12 September to postpone the provisional application of these provisions until 31 December 2015, it is necessary to extend the exemption from customs duties to Ukrainian products until that date. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. – It is important to maintain the EU’s high level of support for Ukraine while also boosting certainty about trade conditions for economic operators. It is thus crucial that Parliament supports an accelerated procedure for considering this Commission proposal, in order to ensure that the prolongation of the granting of autonomous trade preferences can be applied as of 2 November 2014 (i.e. without any interruption) until 31 December 2015. I have therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the Report on Customs duties on goods originating in Ukraine, which deals with the legal vacuum for existing exports from Ukraine to the EU. The report extends the initially granted autonomous trade preferences until the end of 2015 and in particular until application of the trade agreement (the DCFTA) comes into force.

name: Giulia MOI
text: in writing. - (IT) As has already been explained during the debate on this issue in plenary, guaranteeing unilateral tariff preferences to Ukraine is undoubtedly a clear political signal to Russia, but it must not help to further impoverish our producers and, in particular, farmers.  These preferences will, in fact, place EUR 487 million on the Community budget with direct consequences for the agricultural sector, especially ma corn and flour, where Ukrainian exports account for more than 60% and where the reduction in duties will result in losses that are not easily recoverable. These reasons led to my abstention from the vote.

name: Sorin MOISĂ
text: in writing. - The decision of the European Union unilaterally to extend market access to Ukrainian goods on its territory until the end of 2015 is a an act of generosity, showing that there is no such thing as a ‘geopolitical plot’ against any of Ukraine’s traditional partners, notably Russia. Russia’s products will be free of direct competition from EU products in Ukraine, which is a painful condition imposed by Russia on Ukraine and accepted by the EU as part of its effort to facilitate a peaceful resolution of the Ukrainian crisis. In order to enforce this arrangement, the EU agreed to give up on its own market access to Ukraine, as negotiated in the deep and comprehensive free trade agreement (DCFTA), the full enforcement of which will have to wait until 2016. It is a selfless response from the EU, in stark contrast to any zero-sum ‘encirclement’ game. I am also particularly reassured by the introduction of a provision for democracy and human rights conditionality to be respected by Ukraine in exchange for the trade preferences. Ukraine has to behave as a modern liberal democracy, respecting human rights, including minority rights, in order to have the continued solidarity of Western liberal democracies. With the inclusion of these conditions, I was happy to support the measure.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which goes hand in hand with the association agreements we voted on last month. Indeed, the EU-Ukraine Association Agreements, which were approved in an exceptional session, will take effect in December 2015. In order to avoid the legal vacuum and the loss of our trade gains in Ukraine, we have extended the existing free trade agreements until 31 December 2014 until the end of next year.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. - Timeliness is needed to avoid a regulatory vacuum with respect to the removal of customs duties for imports from Ukraine. We believe that trade policy interests must be consistent with those of foreign policy and that at this stage we must send out a strong signal to a people in difficulty.  Thus Ukrainian producers can divert their trade to the European market and are encouraged to adapt to Eu ropean standards. In addition, we think it is a good thing that Article 2 is included, which reaffirms the obligatory respect for fundamental freedoms, the inviolability of borders and the fight against the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction. Finally, in the agricultural and agro-industrial sector, levels of protection remain higher than in other sectors, with minimum quotas and prices not distorting the competitiveness of local products. I am voting for this resolution, in the hope that this extension can be perceived as an act of goodwill on the part of the EU and a stimulus to bring the crisis to an end as soon as possible, certainly not as a way of wasting time, let alone a custom, and we also hope that the real trade treaty will enter into force by 1 January 2016 at the latest.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. - Ukraine is a historical part of the European family of nations and should be brought to the EU both diplomatically and economically. Nevertheless, the EU must realise that, under the current conditions surrounding the conflict in eastern Ukraine and the ongoing sanctions against the Russian Federation, this process is based on unilateral interests of the EU and the US. The risk that another Cold War will be supported by the diplomatic short-sightedness of the common foreign policy of the Member States of the European Union and thus irretrievably building blocs between East and West is supported by the association agreement adopted and by this proposal. I have therefore voted against this motion.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. - In order to help Ukraine in this difficult transition period, it was right to extend the application of EU Regulation No 374/2014 on the reduction or abolition of customs duties on goods originating in Ukraine until 31 December 2015, i.e. until the date in force of the EU-Ukraine Comprehensive Association and Free Trade Agreement. This ensures that Ukraine maintains the existing conditions for access to the EU market and avoids a possible temporary interruption of exports to the EU, which could have created further difficulties for Ukraine at an extremely sensitive political and economic stage for the country.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. - I voted for the extension of customs measures favourable to Ukraine. It must be understood that if Ukraine falls economically, Europe will also suffer. We are therefore temporarily helping Ukraine to resist the Russian embargo by facilitating access to the European market for its products. For now, it shows its effectiveness and yet we do not feel invaded by Ukrainian products! This is a small gesture for Europe, a giant support for Ukraine. Ukraine must be prevented from meeting its gas bills to Russia at all costs, by preventing the country from collapsing. Because if the taps are closed, we find ourselves at the end of the tank as winter approaches. This is a situation that must be avoided at all costs.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the extension of autonomous trade measures for Ukraine because, together with the need to avoid the vacuum and legal uncertainty caused by an end to the current measures and the suspension of the implementation of the EU-Ukraine Trade Agreement until January 2016, this Regulation includes, as a condition for its implementation, respect for human rights by Ukraine. The conditioning is contained in the articulation of the Regulation itself (recital 3 and Article 2) and is fully binding. This measure is part of a set of actions undertaken by the EU to support Ukraine in its peace process, and has been supported by the 28 EU Member States. We European Socialists stand for international trade not to be an end in itself, but a means of promoting sustainable development, respect for human rights, labour and environmental standards in the world, within the framework of political dialogue. We will ensure that the Government of Ukraine properly complies with its commitment to respond to the terms provided for in this Regulation. And, otherwise, we will request the immediate interruption of the trade preferences granted herein.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. - Ukraine is a partner country of the European Union under the European Neighbourhood Policy and its Eastern Partnership. Unfortunately, this eu neighbour is currently facing very serious, complex and absolutely exceptional security, social, economic, complex and absolutely exceptional challenges, justifying equally exceptional support measures on the EU side. I therefore supported this extension of the application of Regulation (EU) No 374/2014 on the reduction or elimination of customs duties on goods originating in Ukraine until 31 December 2015, hoping that this measure can contribute positively to the desirable political and economic stabilisation of Ukraine, noting that this measure is part of a comprehensive peace process for Ukraine, as can be read in the report voted on today.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. - Initially, unilateral trade measures were introduced in April 2014 to provide immediate economic assistance to Ukraine, and were due to expire after six months. However, following the tripartite meeting between Ukraine, the European Union and Russia, the EU agreed to delay the implementation of the trade part of its association agreement with Ukraine until December 2015. I voted in favour of this report so that Ukraine can continue to benefit from uninterrupted trade preferences and for the European Union to prove that it can act quickly and decisively.  In addition, the European Union continues and reaffirms its objectives, as Ukraine will be required to comply with EU health standards as well as human rights, fundamental freedoms and the rule of law in order to benefit from these preferential trade measures.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. - (IT) I have chosen to vote totally against renewing trade preferences for products from Ukraine. The measure was taken too hastily and I had asked and obtained in the INTA Commission to avoid the adoption of the simplified procedure. In addition, I proposed that the measure be given the green light by the World Trade Organization, as was done, likewise, with regard to trade preferences for Pakistan.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - From the outing point we condemn and reiterate our condemnation of the coup d'éerous in Ukraine and the rise of fascist forces to the government. That is why we voted against the EU-Ukraine partnership agreement, as it was the trigger for the coup d'eer, and because the consequences of the free trade agreement will be disastrous for various sectors of the economy by both Ukrainian and some EU countries. Following the EU's alleged support for Ukraine, the imposition of the liberalisation of the economy, deregulation and privatization of various sectors, as well as the dismantling of the Ukrainian productive fabric, which will not have a position to compete with large European companies, is hidden. The peasantry of the European Union and Ukraine will once again be affected by competition from industrial agriculture and the agri-export business. This report aims, in particular, to accompany the entry into force of trade provisions of the EU-Ukraine partnership agreement. That's why I didn't vote for it.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing - Ukraine – our eastern partner – is today a hard-pressed country that we must help. People in eastern Ukraine are suffering from hunger, homeless people are homeless as a result of the war, and innocent civilians – mothers and their children – are dying. I therefore supported the reduction of some and the elimination of additional duties on Ukrainian goods. The aim is to ensure existing conditions for access to the EU market and to minimise the risks of disruption to exports to the EU. This solution is part of a comprehensive peace process in Ukraine respecting the territorial integrity of Ukraine, as well as its right to decide on its future. That regulation will provide support to Ukraine in its extremely difficult economic, political and security situation.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. - I support the European Commission's proposal to extend the application of the Regulation on the reduction or elimination of duties on goods originating in Ukraine until 31 December 2015. This extension of this Regulation until the end of 2015 is only a good representation of the EU's support for Ukraine in its difficult political and economic situation.  Given the known situation between Ukraine and Russia regarding political and commercial relations, the shift from the Russian market to the European one will create the possibility for Ukrainian producers and companies to reduce the negative consequences suffered as a result of Russian trade measures against Ukraine. Taking into account the current situation in which Ukraine faces unprecedented security, political and economic challenges, Parliament's timely and swift approval of the Commission's proposal to extend the Ukraine Regulation will only demonstrate that the European Union can act swiftly, efficiently and in line with its promises to help Europe as a whole.  As the EU seeks to achieve as close a relationship with Ukraine as possible, with a view to its political association and economic integration with the Union, as Ukraine is a priority partner country under the European Neighbourhood Policy and the Eastern Partnership, I think it is important to meet Ukraine and for this reason I support the Commission's proposal again

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. - Regulation (EU) No 2013/2013 374/2014 relates to the reduction or abolition of customs duties on matters originating in Ukraine. Ukraine is one of the main partners within the European Neighbourhood Policy (EPS). The European Union needs even more connectivity with Ukraine, taking into account its political situation and economic ties with the EU.  The reduction, i.e. the abolition of customs duties, will allow for an easier and faster flow of goods, thereby achieving Ukraine's better position on the European market. I believe that the human rights clause entered by this decision will provide the European Union with additional mechanisms that can improve respect for democratic principles, human rights, fundamental freedoms and the rule of law in Ukraine. I also want to say that the common goal of all Member States of the European Union is to provide assistance to Ukraine, which is currently leading certain conflicts to preserve the democratic order and social stability.  The European Union must not allow the Russian Federation to jeopardise fundamental human rights and freedoms within any country in Europe through its actions. I support this resolution because the European Union aims to support ukraine's economic and political stability during this turbulent period.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. - I am voting against this report because the reduction or abolition of customs duties to be imposed on goods originating in Ukraine is a symbolic move by the EU against Russia due to developments in the Crimea region. The EU must turn positively towards Russia.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. - In order to continue to strongly support Ukraine and to strengthen the security of trade conditions for economic agents, it is essential that Parliament resort to an expedited procedure for the consideration of the Commission's proposal, so that the extension can apply from 2 November 2014, without interruption. Retroactive application is certainly possible, but in the event that the extension does not apply immediately after 1 November, companies should operate without a preferential regime and in a context of legal uncertainty while facing increasing burdens, which would slow the pace of Ukraine's exports to the EU.
