Moreover, autonomous trade measures offer Ukrainian companies and producers the long-awaited opportunity to diversify their markets away from an increasingly restrictive Russian market, and encourage them to adapt their standards and operations to EU requirements, thus preparing them for full implementation of the comprehensive and comprehensive free trade agreement from 1 January 2016 at the latest.

name: Yana TOOM
text: Writing. - Ukraine is facing a major humanitarian crisis, resulting in ordinary people suffering. Unfortunately, European aid is very limited. In this situation, any assistance to the Ukrainian economy is welcome, so I support the resolution, although it is an exceptional measure, because, because of russia's so-called counter-sanctions, many EU Member States are essentially trying to do the same and find alternatives to the Russian market.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. - The situation on the EU’s borders is not at all satisfactory. In Ukraine, more than 3 000 people have been killed in fighting this year. Yet the EU and we, as MEPs, must find some way to stop the flames at our borders. It is our duty to do so. We need to have a clear geopolitical vision about what the EU stands for. Our ring is on fire, from the Mediterranean to the eastern flank. Hence, I welcome the agreement to boost commercial links between Ukraine and the EU. This agreement has to go hand in hand with various political elements that strengthen the democratic process, in order to promote a better life for Ukraine’s people.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. - From the outing point we condemn and reiterate our condemnation of the coup d'éerous in Ukraine and the rise of fascist forces to the government. That is why we voted against the EU-Ukraine partnership agreement, as it was the trigger for the coup d'eer, and because the consequences of the free trade agreement will be disastrous for various sectors of the economy by both Ukrainian and some EU countries. Following the EU's alleged support for Ukraine, the imposition of the liberalisation of the economy, deregulation and privatization of various sectors, as well as the dismantling of the Ukrainian productive fabric, which will not have a position to compete with large European companies, is hidden. This report aims, in particular, to accompany the entry into force of trade provisions of the EU-Ukraine partnership agreement. That's why I didn't vote for it.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - We are equally sympathetic to the Ukrainian people. That is why we have finalised the illegal coup d'état supported by the EU and the US. This aid that the EU wants to give to the people of Ukraine we also know in Portugal. In exchange for financial aid, the EU will impose the liberalisation of the economy. It will dismantle the productive apparatus of that country, which is unable to compete with the big European companies.  What the EU wants is not to help. It just wants to extend its market to new consumers and have access to raw materials from Ukraine. If the EU wants to help, demand respect for human rights from ukraine's current coup government. Stop supporting fascist militias that persecute trade unionists and other social activists. That condemn the attempt to illegalize the Communist Party of Ukraine and investigate all crimes committed, with particular emphasis on the crime of Odessa. This is the help the EU should give.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. - Ukraine is a historical part of the European family of nations and should be brought to the EU both diplomatically and economically. Nevertheless, the EU must realise that, under the current conditions surrounding the conflict in eastern Ukraine and the ongoing sanctions against the Russian Federation, this process is based on unilateral interests of the EU and the US. The danger that another Cold War will be supported here and thus irretrievably build blocs between East and West through the diplomatic short-sightedness of EU foreign policy is supported by the association agreement adopted and by this proposal. That is why I voted against.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. - I abstained from this vote because, contrary to the provisions, the EU Commission did not quantify the EU's expected financial loss from the abolition of the customs union. The draft report is also silent on the financial impact of the waiver of customs revenue. Members are therefore voting on an issue on which important details are unknown. I am strongly in favour of free trade, but if the abolition of a customs union leads to a loss of financial revenue for the EU, then the institutions should at least have the courage to admit this and quantify the financial loss.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 374/2014 on the reduction or elimination of customs duties on goods originating in Ukraine. By doing so I lent my continuing support to Ukraine as it continues its struggles with the Russian Federation. I feel it is important to assist the Ukrainians in their efforts to distance themselves from Russia. This vote will significantly assist not only the Ukrainian Government but also its citizens in allowing them to obtain the goods and services they need while at the same time helping to minimise spending. Moreover, I agree completely with the rapporteurʼs comments that: ʽWhile that tendency is very important for Ukraine and its businesses, the economic impact of the increase of Ukrainian exports for the EU, given the asymmetry in economic terms between the two trading partners, is bound to be very small. In addition, the trade concessions reflect the balanced outcome of the negotiations with Ukraine in the context of the DCFTA, and have been carefully determined to provide adequate levels of protection to sensitive sectors in the EU, while at the same time facilitating trade with Ukraineʼ.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. - I voted on the Report on the Commission's proposal to extend trade preferences for Ukraine. I welcome the Commission's decision to urgently forward to the EP its proposal to extend existing trade preferences until 31 December 2015, a measure that will cover the remaining period until the entry into force of the Free Trade Agreement (DCFTA) between the EU and Ukraine. This decision demonstrates, once again, the EU's commitment to supporting Ukraine's European journey. It is part of the series of decisions by which the Union makes concrete attachment to its Eastern Partnership commitments to its partners, be it Ukraine, the Republic of Moldova or Georgia.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: Writing. - If we are to help the people of Ukraine, who, even at the cost of many lives, have chosen a European future, the EU must strongly and in the long term support the building of their democratic institutions, while at the same time removing obstacles to trade between the EU and Ukraine. The volume of exports of goods from Ukraine to the EU increased significantly in the first half of 2014 and this increase almost compensated for the decrease in exports from Ukraine to Russia. In view of Russia's actions, a reorientation from the Russian market to the European market is necessary, and so far this change appears to be progressing successfully. Trade concessions by the EU have been chosen in such a way that increased imports do not endanger sensitive sectors in the EU. The possibility of suspending these preferential trade measures in the event of fraud is also maintained and their granting is conditional on Ukraine respecting democratic principles, human rights, fundamental freedoms and the rule of law. Under these conditions, I was able to support the motion for a resolution tabled in good conscience.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. - With this report, the European Parliament grants discharge for the implementation of the budget of the Office of the Office of the Body of European Governmental Offices for Electronic Communications (BEREC) for the financial year 2012. This comes after a delay, as the discharge had to be postponed by identifying shortcomings in the administration. Several steps have been taken within the organisation to avoid the shortcomings associated with the legality of certain transactions, on the recommendation of Parliament. These include initiatives in the field of financial management and financial management, a detailed checklist for procurement, staff training and measures to increase transparency and avoid conflicts of interest. The European Parliament has exercised its supervisory role and contributed to a better functioning of the organisation concerned.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. - I am sorry to be unable to attend this vote, and therefore wish to communicate my belief that discharge should not be granted to BEREC. Improvements may have been made to BEREC in 2013, but that would be an argument to grant discharge in 2013 – not 2012. I therefore remain opposed to discharge.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The purpose of this report, which is presented to us, is to give a discharge to the management committee of the Office of the European Electronic Telecommunications Regulators' Body on the implementation of the Budget for the 2012 financial year. In view of the observations that are an integral part of this discharge, I have voted unfavourably on this vote.  In these comments, it is requested that the Office better control its future budget given the budget implementation rates of 89.55% and the payment credit rates of 76.57%. As with the EU general budget, the rate of appropriations cancelled and postponed to 2013 is worrying: 28% (compared to 45% in the previous budget year!). Similarly, unused credits still amounted to 14.6% in 2013 (17% in 2012).  Finally, I would also like to deplore the Lack of Transparency of the Office and I note that it has just included in its financial manual a detailed and binding checklist for contracting and the appointment of a market manager...

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted against the text and therefore in favour of granting discharge to the Office of the Body of European Regulators for Electronic Communications.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this report because it confirms that, in 2012, The Office of the Body of European Regulators for Electronic Communications has implemented the budget allocated to it. In granting discharge for 2012, Parliament also commented on more transparent budgetary management for the future on the legality and regularity of transactions, procurement and recruitment procedures, prevention and management of conflicts of interest and internal audit.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted for discharge.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. - Each agency in the European Union is given a budget to ensure its proper functioning. The European Parliament and the Council are co-decision-makers of this budget. It is therefore up to Parliament to control the expenditure of European agencies. The Body of European Electronic Communications Regulators (ORECE) had shown some difficulties in implementing its activities, particularly in the area of recruitment procedures and public procurement. Parliament had therefore voted in favour of deferring the discharge decision to a later date. ORECE has now been working to correct these deficiencies. Parliament has therefore decided to grant discharge to the body in question. I voted in favor of discharge.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the proposal for a decision on discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the Office of the Body of European Regulators for Electronic Communications for the financial year 2012 and I think it is appropriate to make a few comments: From a procedural point of view, I am pleased that the Office has introduced clear procedures and detailed phases and workflows for the use of all financial actors in its financial and accounting manuals; I believe, however, that from the point of view of financial and budgetary management, there is still room for improvement, and I call on the Office to step up its efforts in the field of budgetary control in the future; On the prevention and management of conflicts of interest and transparency, I note that the annual declarations of interest made by the Board of Regulators, the Management Committee and the Administrative Director of the Office have been made available through special sections of the Office's public register of documents, but also that the Office has not provided for a review of its current conflict of interest policy; Finally, the initiatives recently taken by the Office for the Improvement of Communication with European Citizens are to be welcomed.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - (IT) I support Mr Sarvamaa's report, which is based on the importance of the sound, correct and transparent financial management of the European institutions and, in this case, BEREC. Finally, the gaps connected with the legality and regularity of the office's operations have been filled, with the introduction of measures to improve the rates of implementation, control and budgetary monitoring, to address the issues relating to commitments and carry-overs and to the recruitment and training of staff. I therefore welcome the results achieved also with regard to improving communication with European citizens about the impact of this office's work on them.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. - BEREC has continued to show a commitment towards keeping standards of independence, consistency and high quality regulation of electronic communications which benefits European citizens and consequently I have voted in favour.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. - (IT) I am voting against the report on the discharge of BEREC. In the first instance, in April, the discharge was postponed both because of the level of carry-overs of appropriations committed to 2013 of EUR 611 000, indicative of the difficulties in planning financial activities, the recruitment procedures examined revealed significant shortcomings concerning transparency. There were also doubts about limited information on conflict of interest policy, without confirmation of the possible implementation of an appropriate code of conduct. BEREC has therefore tried, in recent months, to meet Parliament's demands, but the rate of cancellation of committed appropriations carried over to 2013 stands at 28%, although there has been a decrease compared to the previous year's rate of 45%. It should be emphasised that absolute rigour is needed with regard to the EU's decentralised agencies.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. - Following the European Parliament's decision in April to postpone the approval of the 2012 management of the OEREC, the EREC took a number of measures to improve the situation, such as better financial planning or strict monthly monitoring. That is why I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of supporting the 2012 discharge for the Body of European Regulators for Electronic Communications. However I believe that other measures should be put in place to ensure the full visibility of the EUʼs budget. Other aspects of their performance have improved significantly. The decision on granting discharge to BEREC was postponed in the spring as there had been concerns about poor performance in 2012. However this was due, in part, to the organisation having been newly established.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. - The postponement of the discharge vote last April for the Body of European Electronic Communications Regulators (ORECE) has paid off. The agency has taken measures to address identified problems such as deficiencies in recruitment procedures and significant room for improvement in public procurement procedures. That is why I voted in favour of granting discharge.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. - The evolution and correction of procedures and standards of operation and management of resources verified in the Body of European Regulators for Electronic Communications demonstrates the relevance and importance of democratic control of the institutions and the good interinstitutional relationship, as factors of credibility and appreciation of the public service to be provided to all citizens of the European Union. Good management and administrative efficiency practices are perfectly framed and even encouraged by full compliance with legislation and regulatory standards.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - At its plenary session in April this year, Parliament adopted the report of the Committee on Budgetary Control which proposed postponing discharge to the 2012 budget of the Office of the Office of Regulators for Electronic Communications. The reason for this postponement was due to problems in the administration of the Office related to the budget and financial management, with commitment and payment appropriations, with the procurement and procurement procedures and with the final annual accounts. The report states that the Office is making an effort to address the problems previously found, particularly with regard to commitment and payment appropriations, such as better budgetary planning and strict monitoring of monthly and annual payments. For this reason, the Committee on Budgetary Control proposes this time to give the discharge for the financial year 2012 to the Office.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing - There was concern that the Authority was performing poorly during 2012, mainly due to the fact that this organisation was only recently established at the time. However, it must be acknowledged that many aspects of performance have significantly improved, such as the rate of implementation of the budget, but also the implementation of payment appropriations compared to the previous period. The Authority has taken a number of steps to address issues relating to commitments and carry-overs, but also to monitor monthly and year-end payments. However, it should also be noted critically that the rate of cancelled commitment appropriations carried over to 2013 of 28% is still high.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. - (IT) I am in favour of granting discharge to the Body of European Regulators for Electronic Communications

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. - I am voting in favour of the 2012 Discharge: Body of European Regulators for Electronic Communications, because I welcome the fact that the audit services have done their job for the smooth economic functioning of the institutions.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. - Given that we were able to establish a sufficient degree of improvement in its performance compared with the situation in 2012, I voted in favour of granting discharge to the Body of European Regulators for Electronic Communications.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. - I voted to provide a resolution for the implementation of the budget of the Office of the Body of European Regulators for electronic communications for the financial year 2012, as measures were taken to make the procedures, steps and processes of work used by financial beneficiaries clearer and better structured.  While budget management has improved slightly, there is still room for better planning of it, and for improving the control of public procurement and employment procedures. I also support the improvement achieved in relation to the Communication of the Office with citizens.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Petri Sarvamaa's report on the discharge for 2012 of the budget of the Body of European Electronic Communications Regulators. Over the summer, ORECE adopted the measures requested by the European Parliament on recruitment procedures and public procurement, removing the remaining obstacles to granting this discharge.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. - I supported granting discharge to the Body of European Regulators for Electronic Communications (BEREC) for the financial year 2012. BEREC has improved its performance significantly and satisfied Parliamentʼs concerns.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. - Following the European Parliament's decision in April to postpone the approval of the 2012 management of the OEREC, the EREC took a number of measures to improve the situation, such as better financial planning or strict monthly monitoring. That is why I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. - In April this year, 30 agencies received a resolution for the implementation of the 2012 budget.  Parliament nevertheless postponed its dismissal as director of the Body of European Regulators for Electronic Communications, namely BEREC.  Key arguments for delaying the granting of a note until October were difficulties in implementing the activities of the Authority itself, shortcomings in recruitment procedures and significant room for improvement in public procurement procedures. The Agency had all summer to find solutions to these problems and the Committee on Budgetary Control adopted a new proposal. I supported the report and welcome the measures taken during the summer, all to address these problems.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. - I voted for this Report which takes note that in order to address the shortcomings related to the legality and regularity of transactions, the Office has included in its Financial and Accounting Manuals clear procedures, detailed steps and workflows to be used by all financial actors. The report also welcomes the fact that processes related to the carry forward exercise were under particular focus.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the proposal for a decision on discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the Office of the Body of European Regulators for Electronic Communications for the financial year 2012. I congratulate the Bureau on its recent achievements in improving communication with European citizens.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. - Last March, the Committee on Budgetary Control pointed out that there were some gaps in the documents presented by the Body of European Regulators for Electronic Communications as justification for managing the funds allocated to it for 2012. On that occasion, the Observatory was invited to improve its management and programming skills, through an improvement in the activity related to budgetary control, and an optimization of procurement and recruitment procedures.  Today, a few months later, I believe that this agency has made up for previous shortcomings by presenting fairly satisfactory budgetary documentation.  It is for these reasons that I have decided to vote in favour of the Sarvamaa report, a text detailing the improvements produced by the Centre, with the aim of increasing the transparency margins of its accounting activity.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. - I voted against the discharge of the Office of the Body of European Regulators, as 'cooperation' with the Council in this regard deprives Parliament of its core competence. The competence of the distribution of funds and, above all, the review of proper use must remain with Parliament.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. Parliament's budgetary discharge power should enable it to enforce the budgetary commitments made by all European institutions and agencies. However, both the Commission and the Council take almost no account of Parliament's votes, including when it refuses discharge. It is a symptom of the democratic impotence of Parliament in the EU. The aim here is to give quitus to the Office of the Body of European Electronic Communications Regulators for the 2013 financial year. This was rejected by Parliament in April 2013 due to a lack of budget and financial management, commitments and deferrals, procurement and recruitment procedures and final annual accounts. Measures have been taken by ORECE to improve the status of commitments and deferrals, as well as better budget planning and strict monitoring of month and year-end payments. However, since the 2013 budget was implemented in a particularly chaotic manner, any discharge given for this exercise is problematic. I'm voting against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. - All The European institutions which depend on the budget of the European Union must be strictly supervised by the Court of Auditors and by all entities with that function. It is necessary to assess whether Community funds are being used well, whether these institutions are meeting the objectives outlined and whether there is no waste of resources. In general, with rare exceptions, to be assessed by known inspections, we can say that the institutions concerned are using the funds made available correctly and meeting the proposed objectives.  This seems to be the case with the Body of European Regulators for Electronic Communications, so I am voting in favour of the discharge for the 2012 accounts.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. - The report has welcomed the measures taken by the Body of European Regulators for Electronic Communications (BEREC) to address the issues that were at hand, including the inclusion of a mandatory and detailed procurement checklist in the Office’s Financial Manual, as well as the changes and improvements made to the existing recruitment procedures such as increased transparency in the recruitment process. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. - I supported Parliament in granting discharge to the Body of European Regulators for Electronic Communications. Despite the fact that the initial discharge was postponed, I acknowledge that there has been some improvement in the EUʼs visibility on the organisationʼs website. Nevertheless, close monitoring is needed to ensure that the presence of the EU budget in this organisation is made fully visible.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text which gives the financial discharge to orECE after an adjournment decided last spring. This new body was created, in parallel with discussions on the future of telecoms, in order to harmonize the various regulations in the Member States. The launch of this body has been difficult and ORECE has put in place important measures to remedy it this summer. The financial discharge is now justified as sufficient guarantees have been provided.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. - The vote was about the discharge of the office of the Body of European Government Offices for Electronic Communications for the financial year 2012. In previous years, the Court of Auditors criticised calls for tenders and procurement practices in this respect. For me, budgetary sovereignty is one of the central rights of any democratically legitimate representative of the people – nothing else must apply to the European Parliament. Citizens' confidence in the European institutions depends very much on the transparency and comprehensibility of their decisions. And, unfortunately, we still consider certain procurement practices to be opaque. A second key problem is linked to the position and self-image of our Parliament. For me, it is unacceptable for discharge to be 'modernised' in such a way that it is carried out together with the Council. It must be reserved for Parliament. In this respect, I stand by my call for the finances and the verification of their proper use to be made subject solely to the democratically legitimate legislator. We owe this to the citizens, particularly in the context of the financial crisis, which has not yet been resolved. I therefore voted against the discharge of the office of the Body of European Government Offices for Electronic Communications for the financial year 2012.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. - (IT) Following mr Sarvamaa's report, I voted in favour of discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the Office of the Body of European Regulators for Electronic Communications for the financial year 2012, also on the basis of the Court of Auditors' report on the annual accounts of the Office.  It should be noted that the Office has introduced clear procedures and detailed workflows into its accounts and that the rate of implementation of the budget and the rate of implementation of payment appropriations are improving compared with the results of the previous year.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. - The digital economy is one of the spearheads of the European Union, in which the Office of the European Communications Regulators works to properly regulate the markets for new technologies.  In this regard, it is necessary to increase vigilance on the shortcomings of the use of the accounts of this body, but also to take into account their good recovery. I am therefore in favour of this report, because without Parliament's approval of the accounts, this young institution could not begin to function fully.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. - The Office of the European Electronic Communications Regulators Agency was the only EU agency that in April 2014 did not receive the go-ahead for its 2012 accounts from this Parliament. The European Court of Auditors included in its 2012 annual report reservations regarding the legality and regularity of certain operations and certain aspects of their management. These shortcomings, explainable to some extent by the recent establishment of this Agency, have been re-addressed. That is why I have decided to support the approval of the accounts of the Office of the Agency of European Electronic Communications Regulators for the 2012 financial year.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. - Last April, the European Parliament took the decision to postpone the discharge of the European Electronic Communications Regulators' Body (ORECE) due to its weaknesses in budget management and planning. It was necessary to give ORECE time to convince Parliament of its ability to correct its weaknesses. Since this postponement decision, checks have taken place and solutions have been found; it is in this sense that I supported this report which grants discharge to ORECE for the 2012 financial year.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. - Parliament postponed the discharge of the 2012 ORECE budget based in Riga in April. Among the causes, the difficulty of operating the activities of the Body, the lack of recruitment procedures and room for improvement in public procurement procedures. ORECE undertook to find solutions to all the problems and, in view of the measures taken, including following the positive assessment of the Committee on Budgetary Control, which decided to grant discharge, I voted in favour.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - Following the European Parliament's decision in April to postpone the approval of the 2012 management of the OEREC, the EREC took a number of measures to improve the situation, such as better financial planning or strict monthly monitoring. That is why I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. - I support the proposal to issue a resolution for the implementation of the budget of the Office of the Body of European Regulators for Electronic Communications for the financial year 2012, as all shortcomings related to recruitment and public procurement procedures that initially delayed the granting of a hearing have now been addressed. I commend the efforts made by the Office to address, in addition to the aforementioned shortcomings, the shortcomings around the legality and regularity of transactions by describing clear procedures, steps and processes of work in its finance and accounting manuals.  A detailed internal control procedure adopted by the Office in order to record all irregular activities in a timely way and eliminate them will enable efficient operation. As the Body of European Regulators for Electronic Communications was set up with a view to applying EU rules to improve the functioning of the single market, I particularly welcome a number of measures that have recorded overall progress in the Office's operations.  Measures to better budget planning and tighter monitoring of monthly payments and end-of-year payments, employment in key posts, clearly defined procurement procedures, the inclusion of measurable targets in order to apply internal control standards relating to objectives and performance indicators, steps taken by the Office to improve communication with European citizens on the impact of their work on them, are sure to contribute to easier execution of business tasks and better evaluation of their business activities.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. - In view of the difficulties that the Body of European Regulators for Electronic Communications has had in relation to employment and procurement, I can state that it has been successful in using the summer months to try to remedy them, and in this respect the CONT Committee adopted a report proposing to issue a statement to the Body of European Regulators for Electronic Communications.  The report welcomes the measures taken to correct shortcomings (e.g. the Finance and Accounting Authority manuals describe clear procedures, detailed steps and work processes that must be used by all financial actors, with a particular focus on procedures related to the execution of transfers of funds), and in line with this report I support the proposal to discharge the Agency to the Body of European Regulators for Electronic Communications.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. - I am voting in favour of this report because the necessary work of the respective departments relating to the implementation of the budget of the Office of the Agency of European Regulators for Electronic Communications for the financial year 2012 has been successfully and transparently completed.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. - I voted in favour of the text. The Office's recent steps to improve communication with European citizens about the impact of its activities on them are significant, including the emphasis on measurable and clearly defined objectives that enable a better evaluation of its activities; The Office has begun to further highlight its status as an EU body by displaying the EU logo on certain pages of its website. It is important that the same be done on the ORECE homepage and systematically in all communications, so as to highlight the contribution of the EU budget to the Office.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted against the report because, although there is some effort on the part of BEREC, absolute rigour is needed with regard to the EU's decentralised agencies. One of the reasons why the discharge was postponed concerns recruitment procedures which revealed significant shortcomings in terms of transparency.  To this problem, doubts have also been added about limited information on conflict of interest policy, without confirmation of the possible implementation of an appropriate code of conduct. BEREC has therefore tried, in recent months, to introduce improvements in the current recruitment procedures in order to respond to the discharge authority's requests to increase transparency, but has not provided for a review of its current policy on conflicts of interest, considering it to be consistent with the Commission's guidelines on the prevention and management of conflicts of interest in the EU decentralised agencies.  For the above reasons, I therefore did not support the report.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. - Following the European Parliament's decision in April to postpone the approval of the 2012 management of the OEREC, the EREC took a number of measures to improve the situation, such as better financial planning or strict monthly monitoring. That is why I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - The reason for this postponement, which proposed postponing discharge to the 2012 budget of the Office of the Office of Electronic Communications Regulators, was due to problems in the administration of the Office related to the budget and financial management, commitment and payment appropriations, procurement and procurement procedures and final annual accounts. The report points out efforts to address the problems previously known and therefore the Committee on Budgetary Control gives discharge for the financial year 2012 to the Office.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. - The discharge of the office of the Body of European Government Offices for Electronic Communications for the financial year 2012 has already been criticised by the Court of Auditors in terms of calls for tenders and in the award of contracts, and is, to me, another sign of the European Parliament's misguided budgetary policy. Especially in times of financial crisis, Parliament reacts by opacity and underlines this state of affairs not only through opaque procurement practices, but above all by the fact that this discharge goes hand in hand with the European Council. In this sense, I voted against this report, because the finances and the examination of procurement and application are the sole amatter of democratically legitimate representatives of the people.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of granting discharge to BEREC because the agency actively seeked solutions to the problems for which it was critisezed. BEREC adopted measures addressing some of the key recommendations from the CONT committee in a timely manner. At the same time, the agency was very cooperative.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Madam President! I am also pleased that Parliament has today taken the decision not to exonerate the European Council. We have also had all the budget debates this week. Although it is probably not directly part of the matter, I would like to ask again and call on the Council to finally pay the arrears in membership contributions that it has caused into the European Union budget. I consider it highly indecent to be a member of a European Union and, as a member state, simply not to fulfil my duties. The first duty, of course, is to meet in Brussels, of course, to help create decent laws, but the most important duty is also to transfer membership fees on time and properly, because that is the only way in which the European Union can remain able to act.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. Parliament is justifiably refusing to grant discharge for the implementation of the budget of the European Council and the Council for the financial year 2012. The European Parliament has repeatedly criticised the Council's lack of cooperation in the present proceedings on several occasions in the past.  The Council's behaviour is unacceptable, because the assessment of the sound financial management is one of the fundamental tasks of every Parliament. This democratic control is necessary to guarantee general transparency in the use of public funds. However, this is precisely what Parliament cannot do because of the lack of cooperation mentioned above. The European Court of Auditors notes errors in its 2012 report, such as the design of procurement procedures. For his part, it makes recommendations. The Council must respond to these recommendations. However, this has not been satisfactorily done. Parliament must also be informed of the actual and likely costs of the 'Europe' building and the 'Residence Palace' building. The Council must finally cooperate properly with Parliament. Otherwise, it tramples underfoot the right of EU citizens to transparency and information.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report, which proposes to deny discharge to the Secretary General of the Council on the implementation of the European Council's Budget and the Council for the 2012 financial year, illustrates in itself all the difficulties of the European Union. On the one hand, a desire for "Eurofederalism" at all costs and on the other, natural differences (cultural, historical or economic) between European peoples and countries that cannot be denied.  Thus, in this struggle in principle between Parliament and the Council lies the perfect failure of these European institutions which want to apply to realities too different remedies that are not suitable.  This report highlights several points that deserve to be raised about the functioning of the EU. For example, errors in the design of procurement procedures or the lack of transparency of the European institutions. Documents requested by Parliament are not transmitted and even better, it is recognised that this "becomes a worrying symptom of a certain practice contrary to democracy in the institutions of the Union". Bossuet would say that "God laughs at men who deplore the effects of which they cherish the causes."  In principle, however, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. - (IT) Thanks to the discharge procedure, the European Parliament exercises ex-post democratic control over the way in which the Union budget is used. I voted in favour of this report and therefore against the adoption of the Council's budget, because this institution has, for too many years, refused to provide the information necessary to enable citizens, through their representatives in Parliament, to control their expenditure.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - (IT) Today I voted in favour of the position of the Committee on Budgetary Control refusing discharge to the Secretary-General of the Council in respect of the implementation of the budget of the European Council and the Council for the financial year 2012. All the Community institutions should be transparent and fully accountable to the citizens of the Union with regard to the funds entrusted to them as institutions of the European Union, I believe that the Council has not been sufficiently transparent. This applies all the more to the European Council and the Council, which should be subject to democratic accountability to the citizens of the Union since they are beneficiaries of the general budget of the European Union. However, the Council's discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the European Council and the Council for the financial year 2012 is characterised by a lack of information and transparency. These shortcomings led me to refuse discharge by the Council.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. - On 5 February, the Council made its recommendations on the discharge to be given to the Commission in respect of the implementation of the General Budget of the European Union for the financial year 2012. Parliament postponed the discharge to Section II - The European Council and the Council. Finally, on 23 September 2014, the Committee on Budgetary Control unanimously refused discharge on the grounds of a lack of cooperation on the part of the Council, lack of transparency on the various costs. As a result, we are unable to control expenditure.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. - (IT) Given that Parliament is the only European institutional body directly elected by the citizens, I am voting positively on the second report on discharge in respect of the implementation of the General Budget of the European Union for the financial year 2012. In addition to raising the issue of administrative transparency, the report draws the Council's attention to the need to make costs for the 'Europe' and 'Residence Palace' buildings transparent. The report therefore calls for discharge not to be granted to the Council.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report which proposes not to give discharge to the 2012 budget of the Council and the European Council, as the Council once again refuses to take account of the questions put by Parliament in the exercise of its right of scrutiny contained in the TFEU and reiterated by the European Commission itself. The Council's lack of cooperation, once again, and its unwillingness for transparency have once again caused Parliament not to grant discharge in 2012.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of refusing the granting of discharge to the Council and European Council as there has been no progress on this matter since the spring. There is still a lack of transparency about the Council’s finances and a continued refusal to provide information in response to committee questions.  The report by the Committee on Budgetary Control states that Parliament is not in a position to make an informed decision. Meanwhile the Commission has indicated that it is not able to oversee implementation of the budget of other institutions, as that would infringe their autonomy. The report also states that citizens’ rights to information and transparency are being denied and that the Council’s conduct shows a democratic deficit. The report calls for a political solution and a procedure to be established on document exchange in order to send positive signals to citizens.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. - In the face of the Council's constant refusal to cooperate with Parliament in the discharge procedure, we have decided to deny it discharge. As a reminder, discharge is the political component of external control of budget implementation. In doing so, the Council thus opposes the right of control of Parliament, while Parliament, as the Chamber of Citizens, is entitled to expect close cooperation from the Council. Only such an attitude would allow Parliament to make an informed decision.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. The European Parliament, the European Union's budgetary supervisory authority, did not grant discharge to the Council for the implementation of the 2012 budget. By refusing to answer our questions, the Council is failing in its duty to inform European citizens and taxpayers. To grant discharge, we must have access to the accounts. As long as the Council refuses to comply, the European Parliament will not be able to grant discharge. That is the very principle of democratic control that our Parliament must exercise.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. - In the name of transparency and rigour in the management of public affairs, I voted in favour of this report, reinforcing Parliament's position in defence of the legality, treaties and rights of European citizens. All the Institutions of the Union must ensure procedures and regulations that ensure transparency and good management in their functioning, making themselves available to assume their full responsibility to European citizens, in particular as regards the funds entrusted to them and it is up to them to use and manage them. In this context, it is important to pay due attention to the Court of Auditors' recommendations that the authorising officers of the European Council and the Council improve the design, coordination and implementation of procurement procedures through appropriate controls and better guidance. I also highlight the importance of clarifying and resolving several outstanding issues, as is the case with the Europa building and the Résidence Palace project. The full provision and clarification of public accounts cannot be treated as acts of interference or dispute of institutional supremacy, but as respect for democracy, legislation and transparency.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - At its plenary session in April this year, Parliament adopted the report of the Committee on Budgetary Control which proposed postponing discharge to the 2012 budget of the European Council and the Council. The problems which led Parliament to postpone discharge relate to the Court of Auditors' assessment, which found errors in the design of procurement procedures, and also by the council's repeated refusal to give detailed information so that the European Parliament can make an assessment of the Council budget. This is an ancient war. Once again, the Council did not respond to Parliament's questions or deliver the documents on the implementation of the budget. Since April, when the European Parliament decided to postpone the discharge, there has been no effort by the Council to answer parliament's questions or resolve the issue. The report is therefore critical of the Council's position and proposes not to give discharge to the Council. As in the financial years 2009, 2010 and 2011.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing - Discharge to the Council has already been refused for 2009, 2010 and 2011 due to a lack of transparency in finances and a continued refusal to provide information to the committee responsible in a manner customary for the other institutions and bodies of the European Union. The citizens of the Member States of the European Union have the right to transparent information, and the Council's behaviour rather points to a democratic deficit and the denial of democratic information to the public. This problem is important to solve politically, thus sending a clear and positive message to the citizens of the Member States. It is important for the Council to respond to the european Parliament's renewed calls and to explain the unanswered questions surrounding the construction of the Europa building and the Résidence project, and also to report on the stage at which administrative modernisation is taking place, in particular as regards specific implementing measures and their impact on the Council budget.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted against granting discharge to the European Council and the Council.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. - I am voting in favour of the 2012 discharge with regard to the European Council and the Council, because all the institutions must cooperate with each other, in particular on controls, and to justify to Parliament the progress of certain projects.

name: Ashley FOX
text: in writing. - I voted for this report refusing to grant discharge to the Council in relation to the financial year 2012. I will continue to vote against the granting of discharge to any part of the EU budget until the budget as a whole receives a positive statement of assurance from the Court of Auditors.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: Written. - (SV) We Swedish Social Democrats chose to vote in favour of not granting discharge to the European Council and the Council. The European Council and the Council have not lived up to the reasonable demands for transparency. As for Parliament - and more broadly for all European citizens - it is absolutely essential to have comprehensive transparency in how the money is spent. Full transparency must apply throughout the EU system."

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. - No supervisory board in the economy would come up with the idea of exonerating a board that disregards the simplest rules of an honourable businessman as much as the European Commission and the European Council. Unpaid bills amounting to billions of dollars have been accumulated over the years, creating a scandalous shadow budget. How can a Parliament agree to such a blatant breach of the most basic budgetary rules? As an authority with the claim to constantly lecture the economy on morality, this Parliament can no longer be taken seriously.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. - I voted to reject the dismiss to the Secretary-General of the Council for the implementation of the Council's budget for the financial year 2012, on the basis that the Council did not respond to the Recommendations of the Court of Auditors, which warned of errors in the design of procurement procedures (such as the application of selection criteria) that should use appropriate checks and more effective guidance. It is also questionable the cooperation provided by the Council on questions from the European Parliament, as Parliament is the only institution that has the responsibility of granting discharge for the implementation of the EU budget.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. The Council does not respond to the many questions that the European Parliament has addressed to it regarding its budget, so it is not possible for the European Parliament to give budgetary discharge to the European Council and the Council with full knowledge of the facts.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of refusing discharge for the implementation of the general budget of the EU for the 2012 financial year, due to a lack of transparency in the finances and the Councilʼs continued refusal to provide information in response to Parliamentʼs questions.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report which proposes not to give discharge to the 2012 budget of the Council and the European Council, as the Council once again refuses to take account of the questions put by Parliament in the exercise of its right of scrutiny contained in the TFEU and reiterated by the European Commission itself. The Council's lack of cooperation, once again, and its unwillingness for transparency have once again caused Parliament not to grant discharge in 2012.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. - I supported this report which insists that the expenditure of the Council must be scrutinised in the same way as that of other institutions, and points out that the fundamental elements of such scrutiny have been laid down in its discharge resolutions of the past years, in particular the discharge resolution of 23 October 2012.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the report signed by Mr Deutsch because, like him, and like the other members of the Committee on Budgetary Control (who voted in favour of the document unanimously), I believe that the Council has a duty to cooperate responsibly with the European Parliament, with a view to ensuring effective and transparent budgetary control.  I therefore agree with the decision to refuse discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the European Council and the Council for the financial year 2012, on the assumption that the European institutions should not miss any opportunity to demonstrate a full democratic attitude.  I therefore regret the countless obstacles encountered during the discharge procedures, which are generally due to a lack of cooperation on the part of the Council.  And I find it distressing that the Latter has, on several occasions, even refused to submit to this Parliament, which shares with it the budgetary authority, the documents requested.  I therefore call on the Council to stop confusing the demand for information on its accounting activities, which is entirely plausible, and in line with the competences of the European Parliament, as an attempt at institutional bypassing.  This prejudice only undermines confidence in the Community institutions, on the part of our citizens, which has already been undermined because of exogenous reasons.  (Explanation of vote abbreviated in accordance with Rule 183 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. Parliament's budgetary discharge power should enable it to enforce the budgetary commitments made by all European institutions and agencies. However, both the Commission and the Council take almost no account of Parliament's votes, including when it refuses discharge. The aim here is to give a quitus on the budget of the European Council and the Council. The text recalls the difficulties systematically encountered so far during the discharge procedures, which are due to a lack of cooperation on the part of the Council. It points out that Parliament refused to give discharge to the Secretary General of the Council for the 2009, 2010 and 2011 financial years and that it adjourned its decision to grant discharge for the 2012 financial year. The resolution confirms that Parliament is not in a position to make an informed decision on the discharge for 2013. I vote for this text without illusions about the democratic impotence of Parliament in the EU.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. - All The European institutions which depend on the budget of the European Union must be strictly supervised by the Court of Auditors and by all entities with that function. It is necessary to assess whether Community funds are being used well, whether these institutions are meeting the objectives outlined and whether there is no waste of resources. In general, with rare exceptions, to be assessed by known inspections, we can say that the institutions concerned are using the funds made available correctly and meeting the proposed objectives.  However, according to the rapporteur's opinion, this is not yet that of the European Council and the Council, so I am voting in favour of the refusal to give discharge to the Secretary-General of the Council for the implementation of the budget of the European Council and the Council for the financial year 2012.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report as it refused to grant the Secretary-General of the Council discharge in respect of the implementation of the European Council’s and the Council’s budget for the 2012 financial year due to the number of issues still pending. This report, like others, reiterates the call to the Council to inform Parliament about the progress on construction, and the final costs projection, of the ‘Europa’ building, and it also reminds the Council of Parliament’s call for a progress report on the ‘Residence Palace’ building project and a detailed breakdown of the costs incurred to date.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. - I refused to grant discharge to the Council due to a lack of transparency in the finances and its continued refusal to provide information in response to Parliamentʼs requests. I believe that our citizensʼ right to information and transparency is paramount for all European institutions.

name: Giulia MOI
text: in writing. - The council's lack of accountability to the European Parliament endangers, first and all, the right of citizens of the Union to information and transparency with regard to the funds entrusted to it as an institution of the Union; It also highlights the democratic deficit in the European institutions.  Since all the institutions should cooperate to ensure the proper functioning of the discharge procedure, my vote in favour of this report is intended to be an invitation to the Council to give priority to the right of citizens to be fully informed and to recognise the European Parliament's right to information.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report which refuses to give the Council financial discharge. The discharge procedure is a mechanism by which the European Parliament exercises democratic control after the fact, with political content, over how the European Union's budget is used. There is no suspicion of financial mismanagement on the part of the Commission. However, the Council has consistently refused to answer questions from the European Parliament on the implementation of its budget. Since 2009, the Council has not received discharge. This decision was motivated to uphold the prerogatives of the European Parliament and to ensure that every citizen has a clear vision of the use of European funds.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. - (IT) I have followed Mr Deutsch's report and what was decided by the Committee on Budgetary Control on 23 September, when it unanimously refused to grant discharge.  I agree with what the draft resolution adopted by the CONT Commission says, because we need greater cooperation between Parliament and the Council - it is not optimal at the moment - and, as has been pointed out several times, an operational procedure should be established between the two bodies that is more cooperative and joint. That is why it is absolutely necessary to find a modus vivendi in agreement between Parliament and the Council on the discharge procedure.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. - The requirement for transparency of the expenditure of the European institutions is a prerequisite for the confidence of the citizens of the Union in their representatives. In this sense, I urge the responsible authorities to clarify the doubts expressed by this report, which I agree with.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. Like many of my colleagues, I supported the refusal to grant discharge on the implementation of the budget to the European Council and the Council for the 2012 financial year, as it has been every year since 2009. Parliament has already had the opportunity to make its case. I would simply point out here that cooperation between all EU institutions is essential in order to ensure the smooth running of the discharge procedure, including through the proper transmission of documents. To date, however, the Council does not fulfil this obligation and fails to answer our legitimate questions as the official discharge authority. This behaviour does not guarantee the full transparency of the European system that we want and which the citizens are asking for.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. - The discharge and Council accounts for the 2012 financial year have already been postponed at last April's plenary meeting for the fourth time in a row, due to the lack of transparency required by this Parliament to the Council. The Council continues to refuse to provide this House with the required documents and to appear before the Committee on Budgetary Control in the context of the regular exercise of the approval of the management of EU accounts.  Since then the situation has not changed and I have therefore voted in favour of the decision not to approve the Council's accounts for the 2012 financial year.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. - Last April, Parliament decided to postpone the granting of discharge to the Council in order to give it more time to comply with the provisions relating to the approval of accounts. However, despite our requests, we have not obtained details on the construction costs of the European Council's new Europa building and we note that the Council has not responded to our recommendations. As a result, I have taken the decision to vote in favour of this report and therefore to refuse the granting of discharge to the Council and the European Council. There is an urgent need for these two institutions to listen to Parliament and take into account its recommendations.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. - The Council and the European Council have not been granted discharge since 2011. In view of the fact that the Council still does not take account of Parliament's requests and refuses to take part in the hearings organised by the CONT Committee, the report proposes that discharge should not be granted again until the Council fully cooperates between the two institutions. That is why I voted in favour of the report proposing to refuse discharge.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report which proposes not to give discharge to the 2012 budget of the Council and the European Council, as the Council once again refuses to be held accountable for the questions put by Parliament in the exercise of its right of scrutiny under the TFEU and reiterated by the European Commission itself. The Council's lack of cooperation, once again, and its unwillingness for transparency have once again caused Parliament not to grant discharge in 2012.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. - On the basis of Parliament's decision adopted on 3 April to postpone discharge to the Council and the European Council, rapporteur Tamas Deutsch proposed in the second draft of his report a refusal to grant discharge again due to the fact that the Council ignores the issues raised by Parliament, such as questions about the costs associated with the Europa building and the Residence Palace and the question of the administration's modernisation process and its measures and the impact on the Council's budget.  The Council also does not participate in the Council's budgetary oversight committee hearings on financial management. I support the proposal to reject the granting of a dismiss until the Council and the European Council have started to respect Parliament's right to fully exercise its powers and to preserve transparency and democratic accountability to EU taxpayers.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. - I am voting in favour of this report because not all the actions required to close the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2012, Section II – European Council and Council have been completed.  The cooperation of all EU institutions with each other and the transparency of all their actions and work is a fundamental stone in the management of public money.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. - I voted for the discharge. It should be added, however, that Parliament and the Council could begin by defining a modus vivendi procedure with a list of documents to be exchanged in order to exercise their respective roles in the discharge procedure. In this regard, I encourage the Council to seek a political solution to the Council's discharge, irrespective of the differing legal opinions on which Parliament and the Council continue to rely: good cooperation between Parliament, the European Council and the Council resulting from an open and formal dialogue procedure could be a positive signal sent to the citizens of the Union.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. - (IT) Parliament is the only European institution directly elected by the citizens. The need for transparent administrative management of the institutions is fulfilled in the discharge procedure: the Council's continuing refusal to provide Parliament with the necessary documents is a refusal on the part of citizens to ensure the proper administration of European funds and poses a serious problem of democracy. The Council seems to want to wage a power struggle to maintain its supremacy over Parliament, without taking into account the right of European citizens to transparent information. The difficulties encountered in the discharge procedures for the financial years 2007-2011 relate mainly to the fact that the Council's expenditure should be subject to the same verification as the expenditure of the other Union institutions, i.e. an assessment based on written documents submitted by all the institutions to the European Parliament.  In particular, the Commission itself has expressed its support for parliament's right to decide on the Council's discharge.  I am therefore voting in favour of the report calling for discharge not to be granted.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report which proposes not to give discharge to the 2012 budget of the Council and the European Council, as the Council once again refuses to be held accountable for the questions put by Parliament in the exercise of its right of scrutiny under the TFEU and reiterated by the European Commission itself. The Council's lack of cooperation, once again, and its unwillingness for transparency have once again caused Parliament not to grant discharge in 2012.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. - Today I voted against granting discharge to the European Council for its general budget for the 2012 financial year due to a lack of financial transparency and the Councilʼs continued refusal to provide information in response to the parliamentary committeeʼs questions. Discharge was also refused for financial years 2009, 2010 and 2011.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. - The European Parliament has the right to control the legality and regularity of the operating expenditure of EU institutions and bodies, through the so-called annual budget discharge procedure. In April 2014, a large majority of the European Parliament decided to postpone the discharge to the Council on its 2012 budget, due in particular to the weak responses of the Council in the context of the hearings and the written question procedure, the lack of anti-fraud policy in the Council's general secretariat, and weaknesses in the procurement procedure. The European Parliament has postponed its discharges to the Council since 2007 without exception. I voted in favour of the EP report refusing to grant discharge to the Council, which had not responded to requests for information. Thus the European Parliament, for once, reaffirms its role as the EU's budgetary authority and shows that the Council is not above the other EU institutions or its budgetary principles, including legality, accountability, transparency and cooperation.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - The problems which led Parliament to postpone discharge to the 2012 budget relate to the Court of Auditors' assessment, which found errors in the design of procurement procedures, and also by the applicant's refusal by the Council to give detailed information so that the EP can make an assessment of the Council's budget. Once again, the Council did not respond to EP questions or deliver the documents on the implementation of the budget. The report is therefore critical of the Council's position and proposes not to give discharge to the Council. As in the financial years 2009, 2010 and 2011.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. - Parliament has been regularly refusing to grant budgetary discharge to the Council and the European Council since 2009. What sums are we actually talking about here? The European Council and the Council spend well over €500 million per year (2011: EUR 563 262 480; 2012: EUR 533 920 000; 2013: EUR 540 511 300. Expenditure of EUR 536 800 000 is expected for 2014 and EUR 542 295 500 for 2015. This money is taxpayers' money from the citizens of the 28 Member States and is spent by the Heads of State or Government on their own responsibility for organising their cooperation at European level. It may have a political taste for such large sums of money to be spent without control. On the other hand, there is no robust legal basis that obliges the Council to disclose its financial management to Parliament. This is therefore a political balance of power between two EU institutions.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: Writing. - I voted in favour of my colleague Tamás Deutsch's report on the discharge for the implementation of the European Union's general budget for the financial year 2012 because I am convinced that it is legitimate to make a series of suggestions rejecting the discharge of the European Council and The Council. This report came after the European Parliament postponed the discharge of the two institutions in April this year. The report regrets that the Council has not cooperated and the requested data have not been provided, without which the European Parliament is unable to take an appropriate decision on discharge. The document proposes to establish a 'modus vivendit' on this subject between the EP and the Council so that Parliament can exercise its powers.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: in writing. - I voted against granting discharge to the Council and the European Council, because this institution does not cooperate with Parliament. It is secretive and non-transparent and it does not answer questions from the Committee on Budgetary Control regarding serious shortcomings, including in the area of public procurement. The members of the institution do not attend hearings of the Committee on Budgetary Control. There are also doubts about transparency with regard to the modernisation of the Council’s new Europa building.

name: Lucy ANDERSON
text: in writing. - I was delighted to vote in favour of this motion for a resolution, securing decent working-time rules for those working on passenger and cargo ships in inland waterways. Inland waterway transport is an important economic sector within which around 10 000 companies across the European Union operate, and it is generally quiet and energy-efficient. We as MEPs have a duty to defend all workers, and this measure proves that it is possible to protect workers with irregular or atypical working hours, without opting out of the Working Time Directive entirely. I am particularly pleased to support the measure given that it is the result of a social partner agreement between employers and workersʼ unions. By engaging in constructive social dialogue, inland waterways employers have recognised the fact that fair working conditions and adequate rest are essential to productive operations. And by negotiating effectively, the European Transport Workersʼ Federation has demonstrated that there is no reason for inland waterway workers to be deprived of basic protections, including limits on working time, rights to rest periods, and night work restrictions. I hope that those who claim that a blanket opt-out of the Working Time Directive is necessary will rethink their position following this excellent result.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. In the European Union, more than 40,000 people work in the river transport sector, of whom 31,000 (77%) are mobile workers.  This report, which is in line with more social protection for these workers, leaves it up to Member States and/or social partners to adopt measures that are more favourable to workers in this field. It is a prerequisite for the development of river transport that must be encouraged.  For these reasons, I support the European agreement between the European Union for River Navigation (UENF), the European Boatmen's Organisation (EPO) and the European Transport Workers' Federation (ETF) on certain (positive) aspects of work arrangements in the inland navigation sector.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of this short resolution in which Parliament welcomes the agreement on minimum levels of protection for workers operating in the inland waterway transport sector, guaranteeing them a potential defence against the strong social dumping caused by workers in Eastern Europe.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted today in favour of the motion for a resolution on the Europe Agreement concluded between the European Barge Union (EBU), the European Organisation of Captains (ESO) and the European Federation of Transport Workers (ETF) concerning certain aspects of the organisation of working time in inland waterway transport. I welcome the fact that the agreement concluded by the social partners and the Commission's proposal only provide for minimum requirements, leaving Member States and/or the social partners the freedom to take measures that are more favourable to workers in the sector concerned.  Working and living conditions on passenger ships differ from those of other ships intended for inland waterway transport. The diversity of the social environment and operational activities, combined with the seasonal nature of this segment of the European inland waterway transport sector, determine a different organization of work. All these factors justify the existence of special provisions.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - (IT) I am voting in favour of this resolution since the provisions of Directive 2003/88/EC did not take sufficient account of special working and living conditions in the inland waterway transport (TVN) sector. More specific requirements, on the other hand, will ensure a high level of protection of the safety and health of workers in this sector. Inland waterway transport has an international dimension and is mainly characterised by cross-border inland waterway activities. That is why better conditions on the labour market should be promoted and unfair competition based on differences in legislation should be prevented. I believe that the proposal is in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity and proportionality and that the new rules will make it possible to improve an environmentally friendly transport carrier, which contributes in a sustainable way to decongesting European freight transport by road and rail.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. - I voted in favour in support of a measure that aims at securing better conditions for workers, even if Member States ought to be encouraged to provide more than the minimum required in this agreement.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. - (IT) I am voting in favour because this would give Member States and the social partners the freedom to take measures that are more favourable to workers in the inland waterway transport sector at EU level.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. - I did not vote in favour of this resolution on the European agreement concluded by the European River Navigation Union (EBU), the European Boat Patterns Organisation (ESO) and the European Transport Workers' Federation (ETF) on certain aspects of the organisation of working time in inland waterway transport because, although it may seem like an agreement to improve the social arrangements of workers in this sector , is another example of down-down social harmonization. That's why I abstained.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. - This motion proposes an agreement which sets minimum rules on working time for passenger and cargo transport ships in inland navigation across the EU. The new rules apply to crew members and shipboard personnel and complement the general Working Time Directive which does not cover inland waterway workers. This means that this sector will be better regulated while protecting such workers. Hence I supported this resolution.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. - The vote on this text is important in two ways. Firstly, it demonstrates the ability to form agreements at EU level between the social partners. Secondly, I welcome the fact that the European Parliament has been consulted on this proposal for a directive implementing the European agreement reached by the European Union of River Navigation (UENF), the European Boatmen's Organisation (EPO) and the European Transport Workers' Federation (ETF) even though the Treaty does not provide for any obligation to do so. This is a positive sign to strengthen the democratic legitimacy of the European Union's decisions.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. River navigation professionals are subjected to irregular work rhythms. Boats sail an average of 14 hours a day and often several consecutive days. Hence the need to implement its own legislation on the working time of flight attendants, as the General Working Time Directive does not allow these specific needs to be taken into account.  The transposition of the agreement between the social partners on minimum working time requirements on ships is a good answer. Workers in this sector will now be able to benefit from legislation adapted to their activity.  This proposed directive makes mandatory the agreement of 15 February 2012 between the social partners (European Union of River Navigation, European Boatmen's Organisation and European Transport Workers' Federation) on the arrangement of working time in inland navigation, which sets certain minimum guarantees for workers (working time, rest time, annual leave). This text therefore endorses the principle of an increased use of dialogue between social partners to change the union's social law.
