This is a necessary step in promoting European social democracy to which I am committed.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. - In the 28 EU Member States, around 42,200 people work directly in the inland waterway transport sector, with 31,000 mobile workers (73%). Approximately 9,650 companies operate in the inland waterway transport sector.  This proposal lays down requirements for mobile workers in the inland waterway transport sector. The agreement concluded by the social partners in the inland waterway transport sector takes into account the Working Time Directive and proposes a number of specific requirements, in line with the characteristics of the sector, in particular as regards the reference period. In addition, it provides for a minimum number of hours of daily and weekly rest and a maximum number of hours of night work, in order to meet the working conditions and specific characteristics of the sector. The agreement applies to both navigation staff (crew) and on-board personnel, covers the carriage of passengers and goods and contains specific provisions for seasonal work on passenger ships. It does not apply to persons operating ships on their own account (owner-operators).  I voted in favour.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - The agreement on specific aspects of the organisation of working time in the inland waterway transport sector lays down minimum safety and health requirements which have positive aspects. Such as the right to at least four weeks of paid annual leave and to benefit from free annual health examinations. However, many of the principles established go against the demands of workers in the sector, particularly in Portugal. The agreement provides for an average working time of 48 hours, when Portuguese law establishes 40 hours. It also establishes that the maximum reference period is 12 months, which allows working hours of more than 8 hours. In addition to other provisions that can lead to greater flexibility and deregulation of working hours.  Although the objectives of the Directive are the protection of workers' health and safety in a sector which has predominantly cross-border characteristics, it is necessary to ensure that the most favourable national legislation is not undermined by the application of the Directive.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing - The European Commission's proposal in question lays down specific rules on working time in the inland waterway sector by introducing an agreement reached at European Union level between employers' and employees' representatives. The agreement in question lays down minimum rules on working time for staff of passenger and freight transport by ships inland. The new rules will apply to crew members and cabin crew and will complement a general directive that does not include workers in the inland waterway sector. This agreement should contribute to improving working conditions for the 31 000 crew members.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the report setting out the agreement reached at European level between companies and workers - specifically in the inland waterway transport sector. The agreement defines minimum levels of protection for workers. For the rest, it remains the responsibility of the individual Member States.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. - My vote will be negative for the European agreement on certain elements of the organisation of working time in the field of inland waterway transport. I believe that this agreement does not adequately protect workers.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. - I voted for a resolution on the proposal for a Council directive on the implementation of the European Agreement, concluded between the European Association of Inland Navigation, the European Shipping Organisation and the European Transport Workers' Federation on the establishment of certain aspects of the organisation of working hours in inland navigation, primarily because the agreement allows Member States and/or social partners to decide on the best criteria for workers.  It is of utmost importance to take into account the views, recommendations and suggestions of actors who are directly in contact with the area concerned, on the principle of subsidiarity, because it is they who know the best issues, and accordingly the most useful solutions for it.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Marita Ulvskog's resolution on working time in the navigation sector. This text calls on the Commission to ratify an agreement proposed by the various professional organisations of river navigation to complete the Working Time Directive taking into account the specificities of this sector and aiming at harmonising the rules applicable in the various Member States. This resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. - I welcome the implementation of the social partnersʼ agreement on working time for the inland waterway transport sector. This proposal, once agreed by the Council, will contribute to improving working conditions for 31 000 crew members and shipboard personnel and to fairer competitive conditions for the 9 645 enterprises active in the sector.

name: Jérôme LAVRILLEUX
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, of which I was the reference for the French EPP delegation.  It aims to recommend the implementation of a directive to implement the European agreement concluded by the social partners in the inland navigation sector.  This agreement responds to the vacuum of the "working time" directive on river carriers and will contribute to the fight against social dumping.  It covers work or rest time, leave, seasonal work, and the safety and health of workers.  This text sets minimum requirements for Member States, which will remain free to set their own rules.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: In writing. The text proposed to us is a resolution giving Parliament's position on the agreement between trade unions and employers on the working time of boatmen. These flight attendants are in a Bolkestein-type situation insofar as they can practice their profession in a state that is not the one where their contract is established, which can create a situation of social dumping on their working conditions.  The agreement negotiated between trade unions and employers on the working time of boatmen is a step forward, as it introduces minimums on working and rest times. However, this agreement does not address the problem of dumping in the profession, which will continue due to the existing differences between the different labour rights. That is why I abstained so as not to block this minimum from the European social dialogue but which remains inferior to what is practiced in France and therefore leaves open the possibility of unfair competition between European boatmen.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. - I did not vote in favour of this resolution on the European agreement concluded by the European River Navigation Union (EBU), the European Boat Patterns Organisation (ESO) and the European Transport Workers' Federation (ETF) on certain aspects of the organisation of working time in inland waterway transport because, although it may seem like an agreement to improve the social arrangements of workers in this sector , is another example of down-down social harmonization. That's why I abstained

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. - I welcome the fact that the Agreement as concluded by the social partners and the Commission proposal provide only for minimum requirements, leaving the Member States and/or social partners free to adopt measures which are more favourable to workers in the area concerned.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the Europe Agreement concluded between the European Barge Union (EBU), the European Organisation of Captains (ESO) and the European Federation of Transport Workers (ETF) because the proposal adopted by the Commission provides only minimum requirements, leaving Member States and/or the social partners the freedom to take measures that are favourable to workers in the sectors concerned.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. - I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution because studies show that accidents and accidents caused by human error could have been avoided if the crew had been rested. The agreement concluded is the first step in the right direction, and more far-reaching national rules can be made.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. An agreement was reached on 15 February 2012 between the social partners (European Union of River Navigation, European Boatmen's Organisation and European Transport Workers' Federation) on the arrangement of working time in inland navigation. In particular, it sets out certain guarantees for workers: working time, rest time, annual leave. The proposal aims to make the terms of the agreement effective after an initial opposition from the Council. I'm voting for.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. - It is beneficial that the agreements concluded by the social partners with the Commission provide only for minimum requirements, leaving the Member States and/or the social partners the freedom to adopt measures that are more favourable to workers in the field concerned. These are matters on which each Member State should be able to negotiate according to the needs of the sectors concerned. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. - The resolution welcomes the fact that the Agreement as concluded by the social partners and the Commission proposal provide only for minimum requirements, thus leaving the Member States free to adopt other measures which are more favourable to the workers involved in the area. I have therefore voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which now ensures a minimum harmonisation of working time in the inland navigation sector. This text is the validation of an agreement between social partners that sets a maximum ceiling for hours worked. It is not a regulation of working time as we can hear in the classical sense, but rather an agreement to eliminate social dumping and the most extreme practices. The inland navigation sector (mainly river) has an important future in achieving our environmental and re-industrialisation objectives of Europe. The text provides flexibility for workers so as not to penalise them and to maintain the competitiveness of the sector.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. - The motion for a resolution concerned a European agreement on the regulation of certain aspects of the organisation of working time in inland waterway transport, concluded by the European Inland Navigation Union (EBU), the European Shipowners' Organisation (ESO) and the European Transport Workers' Federation (ETF). Although the Commission does not provide for Parliament to be consulted on the question under Article 155(2) TFEU, the Commission has forwarded its proposal to Parliament and, at the same time, asked it to give its opinion to the Commission and the Council. Convinced that democratic participation and parliamentary sovereignty are the foundations on which the European Union project rests, I would like to encourage the Commission to consult more frequently of this kind. In addition, the nation states and the preservation of their sovereignty have always been a central concern for me. Against this background, I very much welcome the fact that this document only provides for the institutionalisation of minimum standards, but leaves the Member States the remaining regulatory space. Last but not least, I also support the substance of the proposal: frequent accidents on the major inland waterways as a result of human error highlight the need to prevent the fatigue of crews. I therefore voted in favour of the motion.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the proposal for a Council directive implementing the Europe Agreement concluded between the European Barge Union (EBU), the European Organisation of Captains (ESO) and the European Federation of Transport Workers (ETF) on certain aspects of the organisation of working time in inland waterway transport. Article 155(1) TFEI gives the social partners at Union level the opportunity, if they so wish, to enter into a dialogue which may lead to contractual relations, including agreements. Paragraph 2 of the same Article provides for the possibility of implementing agreements concluded at Union level, at the joint request of the signatory parties, on the basis of a Council decision on a proposal from the Commission. I welcome the fact that the agreement concluded by the social partners and the Commission's proposal only provide for minimum requirements, leaving Member States and/or the social partners the freedom to take measures that are more favourable to workers in the sector concerned.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. - (IT) I am pleased that agreement has been reached between the European Barge Union, the European Organisation of Captains and the European Transport Workers' Federation on the organization of working time, in a climate of constructive dialogue. In addition, the agreement concluded between the social partners and the Commission, as indicated in the resolution, provides only for basic indications, leaving it to the Member States, in agreement with the social partners, to take the measures that are most favourable to workers in this sector.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution to recommend the adoption of the agreement concluded by the social partners on certain aspects of the organisation of working time in inland navigation transport. This proposal will contribute to improving the working conditions of the 31,000 crew members and other affected personnel, setting minimum conditions for weekly and night working time, and the rights to paid annual leave and daily and weekly rest. The agreed proposal will also provide fairer conditions of competition for the 9,465 companies in the sector in the EU.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I supported this resolution which recommends the adoption of the European Commission's proposal on a specific regulation of working time in the inland navigation sector. This text is the result of an agreement reached at European level by representatives of employers and workers in the sector.  This agreement establishes minimum working time requirements for passenger and cargo vessels. It will provide adequate working conditions and rest periods for workers in the sector; conditions essential to the health and safety of the crew and flight attendants.  There was an urgent need to reach an agreement given that more than 75% of river transport in the European Union is carried out at the transnational level. These measures would ultimately contribute to better working conditions for 31,000 workers and to the establishment of more fair competition among the 9645 companies in the sector.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the agreement which makes it possible to find solutions favourable to all the categories concerned on the subject of the organisation of working time in transport.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - I did not vote in favour of this resolution on the European agreement concluded by the European River Navigation Union (EBU), the European Boat Patterns Organisation (ESO) and the European Transport Workers' Federation (ETF) on certain aspects of the organisation of working time in inland waterway transport because, although it may seem like an agreement to improve the social arrangements of workers in this sector , is another example of down-down social harmonization. That's why I abstained.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. - I welcome todayʼs vote on the implementation of the social partnersʼ agreement on working time for the inland waterway transport sector. We expect the same now regarding the social partnersʼ agreement on health and safety in the hairdressing sector. The outgoing Commission refused to forward the agreement to the Council for its legal transposition. This is severely hampering the autonomy of social partners and questioning their role in European social dialogue.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. - I support the proposal for the implementation of the European Agreement concluded between the European Association of Inland Navigation (EBU), the European Shipping Organisation (ESO) and the European Transport Workers' Federation (ETF) on identifying certain aspects of the organisation of working hours in inland navigation.   In my view, the working hours of inland navigation workers are of u u essence for the health and safety of workers in the workplace. Minimum standards should be set for the organisation of working hours in terms of daily and weekly rest, numerical limits on weekly working hours, annual leave and working hours at night, in order to better carry out the work. I support the Working Time Directive, as it covers specific working conditions such as the shortest daily and weekly rest time and the longest working hours at night due to the specific working conditions and specific characteristics of the sector.  I support the Council's decision that a Member State has the freedom to define all those terms in an agreement that are not defined, in accordance with their national law and practice. Member States may assign social partners, at their joint request, to implement this Directive, provided that they take all necessary measures to ensure that they can guarantee the results set out by this Directive at any time.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. - In 28 EU Member States, over 40 000 people work directly in IWT (inland waterway transport), of which 31 000 are mobile workers (73%). The lack of EU laws that determine the number of hours workers are allowed to work daily allows many local laws to work difficulties for companies engaged in transporting goods and goods, and does not ensure sufficient protection for workers in many cases.  This agreement will further define workers' rights, determine their working hours and the days they are allowed to spend on holiday. Maximum working hours during the night and vacations will be adjusted. New rules will also be introduced concerning the protection of workers, ensuring their health is taken care of.  As one of its objectives, the EU is trying to move the transport of goods to cleaner, safer and low-energy transport methods. Together with shorter-haul rail and sea transport, continental water flow transport can make a significant contribution to the sustainability of the transport system, which will have a successful impact on the European economy.  For these reasons, I support the European Agreement concluded between the European Association of Inland Navigation (EBU), the European Shipping Organisation (ESO) and the European Federation of Transport Workers (ETF) on determining certain aspects of the organisation of inland navigation working hours.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. - I am voting against this agreement because it does not adequately protect workers in this sector.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. - I voted in favour of the European agreement reached by the European Union of River Navigation (UENF), the European Boatmen's Organisation (EPO) and the European Transport Workers' Federation (ETF) on certain aspects of working time arrangements in the inland navigation sector. It should be noted that we can only welcome the fact that the agreement reached by the social partners and the Commission's proposal provide only minimum requirements, leaving the power to Member States and/or social partners to adopt measures that are more favourable to workers in the area concerned.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. - I did not vote in favour of this resolution on the European agreement concluded by the European River Navigation Union (EBU), the European Boat Patterns Organisation (ESO) and the European Transport Workers' Federation (ETF) on certain aspects of the organisation of working time in inland waterway transport because, although it may seem like an agreement to improve the social arrangements of workers in this sector , is another example of down-down social harmonization. That's why I abstained.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. I voted against this European Parliament's resolution on a commission proposal for a directive on an agreement between the social partners on the arrangement of work in inland navigation. In this area, the European Parliament can only give an opinion on this sector excluded from the Working Time Directive. I found that not all trade unions had participated in the negotiation and that while this agreement could improve social provisions in some Member States, it was very regressive for the law applicable in France. Although the agreement provides that the more favourable provisions in the Member States will be maintained, the provisions of the country where the boat is armed will apply when navigation is done on a "cross-border" river axis. There is no doubt that companies that can apply the most favourable law will seek solutions that will enable them to be the most competitive at the expense of social rights.  I can therefore only see it as an instrument of social dumping at the expense of French employees and in particular dockers. Under the guise of improvements in some Member States, this agreement is a way of levelling the social gains from the bottom up.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - The agreement has positive aspects, such as the right to at least four weeks of paid annual leave and the benefit of free annual health examinations. However, the agreement provides for an average monthly working time of 48 hours, when Portuguese law establishes 40 hours and also establishes that the maximum reference period is 12 months, which allows working hours of more than 8 hours.  It is necessary to ensure that the most favourable national laws are not undermined by the application of the Directive.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. - The motion for a resolution on a European agreement on the regulation of certain aspects of working time in inland waterway transport, concluded by the European Inland Navigation Union (EBU), the European Shipowners' Organisation (ESO) and the European Transport Workers' Federation (ETF), not only emphasises the importance of minimum standards designed to prevent accidents or major accidents on major inland waterways, but leaves the remaining or detailed requirements to the Member States. In the sense that, on the one hand, the Commission, together with the Council, showed a certain degree of transparency and that a decision was taken here also in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity, I voted in favour of the motion.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. - The agreement on specific aspects of the organisation of working time in the inland waterway transport sector lays down minimum safety and health requirements at work, which has positive aspects such as the right to at least four weeks of paid annual leave or the benefit of free annual health examinations. However, many of the established principles go against the demands of workers in the sector, particularly in Portugal. The agreement provides for an average monthly working time of 48 hours, when Portuguese law establishes 40 hours. It also establishes that the maximum reference period is 12 months, which allows working hours of more than 8 hours, in addition to other provisions that can lead to greater flexibility of working hours.  While the objectives expressed in the Directive are the protection of workers' health and safety in a sector with predominantly cross-border characteristics, it is necessary to ensure that the most favourable national legislation is not undermined by the application of the Directive.
